class=\"access-state-logos all-viewports\">\r\n                    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    <span class=\"small-caps\">Space\u00a0Warps</span>\u2013 II. New gravitational lens candidates from the CFHTLS discovered through citizen science\r\n<i class='icon-availability_free' title='Free' ></i>                </h1>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n                            <div class=\"meta-authors--limited\">\r\n                                    <span () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"icon-menu_share\"></i>\r\n                                <div class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Share</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                            </a>\r\n                            <ul id=\"ShareDrop\" class=\"addthis_toolbox addthis_default_style addthis_20x20_style f-dropdown\" data-dropdown-content aria-label=\"submenu\">\r\n                                <div class=\"arrow-up\"></div>\r\n                                <li><a class=\"addthis_button_email\"><span>Email</span></a></li>\r\n                                <li><a     <li><a class=\"addthis_button_compact\"><span>More</span></a></li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                    <div class=\"toolbar-search\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SitePageHeader widget-instance-OUP_ArticleToolbarSearchBox\">\n        \r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"dropdown-panel-wrap\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-search-dropdown\">\r\n        <div class=\"mobile-search-inner-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                    <div                  <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"mobile-navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                            <optgroup label=\"Search within this class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin dummy-link js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            University of Utah\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nUniversity of Utah\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f455%2f2%2f1191%2f1103045\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050517 id=\"92050517\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery of 29 promising (and 59 total) new lens candidates from the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS) based on about 11 million classifications performed by citizen scientists as part of the first S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens search. The goal of the blind lens search was to identify lens candidates missed by robots (the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> on galaxy scales and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> on group/cluster scales) which had been previously used to mine the CFHTLS for lenses. We compare some properties of the samples detected by these algorithms to the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> sample and find them to be broadly similar. The image separation distribution calculated from the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> sample shows that previous constraints on the average density profile of lens galaxies are robust. S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> recovers about 65\u2009per\u2009cent of known lenses, while the new candidates show a richer variety compared to those found by the two robots. This detection rate could be increased to 80\u2009per\u2009cent by only using classifications performed by expert volunteers (albeit at the cost of a lower purity), indicating that the training and performance calibration of the citizen scientists is very important for the success of S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>. In this work we present the SIMCT pipeline, used for generating <em>in situ</em> a sample of realistic simulated lensed images. This training sample, along with the false positives identified during the search, has a legacy value for testing future lens-finding algorithms. We make the pipeline and the training set publicly available.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050519 id=\"92050519\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The last few decades have seen a rise in the discoveries of strong gravitational lenses owing to the plethora of interesting applications lenses have in astrophysics and cosmology. Strong lenses are routinely used to probe the dark matter distribution from galaxy (e.g. Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Leier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) to group and cluster scales (e.g. Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), to study distant young galaxies by using the lensing magnification as a natural telescope (e.g. Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Zheng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Whitaker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), to test the cosmological model by constraining cosmological parameters such as the Hubble constant and the dark energy equation of state (e.g. Suyu &amp; Halkola <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Collett &amp; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Sereno &amp; Paraficz <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and many more. Strong lenses are rare, because a foreground massive object needs to be sufficiently aligned with a distant background source to produce multiple images. Nevertheless, systematic lens searches have led to the discovery of over 500 lenses to date.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The search for gravitational lenses is a needle-in-a-haystack problem. Several automated lens-finding algorithms have been developed so far (e.g. Lenzen, Schindler &amp; Scherzer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Alard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Seidel &amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Brault &amp; Gavazzi <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), but they cannot simultaneously capture the myriad types of lenses that are known to exist. For example, the lensed images of background galaxies show variety in their surface brightness distributions, colours, light profiles, shapes, structures and angular image separations. Moreover, many lensed images appear similar to features found commonly in galaxies (such as spiral arms) or to artefacts in astronomical images (scattered light around stars). Almost all lens-finding algorithms find it difficult to distinguish these from the real lenses and thus suffer from a high rate of false positive detections. To mitigate this problem, algorithms are often restricted to detect a very narrow class of lens systems. However, even after such restrictions, robotic lens searches have to always rely on visual screening to produce a sample of plausible lens candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recognizing patterns is one of the strengths of the human brain. Humans are also capable of dealing with multitiered complex web of questions before arriving at a conclusion, a process which may not be always possible to automate. The algorithm by which our brains process a task is extremely malleable, self-learning and self-evolving. Therefore it has a huge potential for the discovery of exotic objects which do not quite fit a set criteria, but are still very likely to be objects of interest. The lens-finding algorithms are not yet advanced enough to produce better performance than visual classifications. Consequently, as we enter the era of large area imaging surveys spanning thousands of square degrees, the participation of a large community of volunteers to help with the visual identification of lenses would be very beneficial for the lensing community. Now seems the perfect time to investigate the potential of citizen science.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">G<span class=\"small-caps\">alaxy</span>\u00a0Z<span class=\"small-caps\">oo</span>, one of the most successful citizen science projects in astronomy, addressed the problem of how to classify large numbers of galaxies by their morphology (Lintott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). From these early results to several new unexpected and interesting discoveries, such as that of green pea galaxies (Cardamone et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Jaskot &amp; Oey <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and Hanny's Voorwerp (Lintott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Keel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), G<span class=\"small-caps\">alaxy</span>\u00a0Z<span class=\"small-caps\">oo</span> has been able to start to realize the potential of citizen scientists. Since then, both astronomy and non-astronomy projects have been launched under the citizen science web portal Zooniverse (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://zooniverse.org\" target=\"_blank\">http://zooniverse.org</a>). The task of finding gravitational lenses is significantly challenging, given that the lens systems show such complexity and that they are rare. To add to the challenge, not many citizen scientists are expected to be aware of the phenomenon of gravitational lensing, and the resulting characteristic image configurations. With these significant challenges at hand, we designed the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> project to enable the discovery of lenses through citizen science (learning from previous experience in serendipitous identification of lens candidates in G<span class=\"small-caps\">alaxy</span>\u00a0Z<span class=\"small-caps\">oo</span>). In a companion paper (Marshall et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper I</a>), we describe the design of S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> and how the entire system functions as a discovery service. In this paper (Paper II), we describe our first lens search using data from the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a>). In K\u00fcng et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), we describe the design of a collaborative mass modelling tool that can be used by citizen scientists.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we introduce the CFHTLS imaging data and the previously published lens samples from the CFHTLS. We generated a training sample, consisting of simulated lenses, duds and impostors, in order to aid the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> volunteers in the process of finding lenses. We give details of this training sample in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> and Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we briefly describe how the classifications of images from the volunteers are turned into a catalogue of plausible candidates (for further details, see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper I</a>). In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>, we present the new lens candidates from S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> and compare it to the lens samples produced by past robotic searches of the CFHTLS. Next, we discuss what kind of lenses are detected or missed by the algorithms and S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>. Our conclusions are given in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050525 id=\"92050525\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 DATA</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050526 id=\"92050526\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 The CFHT Legacy Survey</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The CFHTLS is a photometric survey in five optical bands (<em>u</em>*<em>g</em>\u2032<em>r</em>\u2032<em>i</em>\u2032<em>z</em>\u2032) carried out with the wide-field imager MegaPrime which has a 1\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> field-of-view and a pixel size of 0.186\u00a0arcsec (Gwyn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The CFHTLS Wide covers a total non-overlapping area of 160\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> on the sky and consists of four fields <em>W</em>1, <em>W</em>2, <em>W</em>3 and <em>W</em>4. The field <em>W</em>1 has the largest sky coverage of 63.7\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>. The fields <em>W</em>2 and <em>W</em>4 have similar sky coverages of 22.6 and 23.3\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>, respectively.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> The field <em>W</em>3 has a sky coverage of 44.2\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> and is more than twice as large as <em>W</em>2 and <em>W</em>4.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The CFHTLS imaging is very homogeneous and has good image quality. Most of the lensed arcs are much brighter in the <em>g</em> band, so deep imaging in this band is desirable. The limiting magnitude is 25.47 for the <em>g</em> band which goes the deepest among all of the five bands. The mean seeing in the <em>g</em> band is 0.78\u00a0arcsec. The zero-point to convert flux to AB magnitude for all bands is 30. These characteristics make CFHTLS ideal to do visual inspection for finding lenses. We use the stacked images from the final T0007 release taken from the <span class=\"small-caps\">terapix</span> website (see footnote 3) for this work.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that the CFHTLS is a niche survey with a unique combination of wide imaging with deep sensitivity. It is a precursor to the ongoing wide imaging surveys such as the Dark Energy Survey (DES), Kilo Degree Survey and the Hyper Suprime-Cam (HSC) survey and other planned future surveys such as the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) survey. The search for lenses with S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> in the CFHTLS is an important step to learn lessons and prepare for lens searches in these larger imaging surveys.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050530 id=\"92050530\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Previously published lens samples from the CFHTLS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The CFHTLS has been searched for lenses using various lens-finding methods and algorithms. Here, we give a brief summary of previously published lens samples in the chronological order.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From the early release of the CFHTLS (T0002) covering 28\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>, Cabanac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) used an arc-finding algorithm (Alard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) to find arcs in galaxies, groups and clusters. They found about 40 lens candidates with quality grades from low to high.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the thesis dissertation of Thanjavur (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), nine promising and two low-probability candidates were reported as having been discovered serendipitously. These detections were made during the visual inspection of the CFHTLS images as part of data reduction procedures for the Weak Lensing survey (Benjamin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sygnet et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) carried out a search for edge-on disc galaxy lenses in the CFHTLS Wide. They identified galaxies, using SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span>, which had 18\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>i</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a021 and inclination angle &lt;25\u2009\u00b0. After applying few more selection criteria and visual inspection, they found about 3 promising and a total of 18 lens candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> (More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) was used for finding blue arc-like features in the entire CFHTLS imaging without any pre-selection on the type of the lensing object. This <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span>, an improved version of the algorithm by Alard (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), measures the second-order moments of the flux distribution in pixels within small regions to estimate the direction and extent of local elongation of features. Pixels with high values of elongation are connected to form an arc candidate. Finally, a set of thresholds on arc properties such as the area, length, width, curvature and surface brightness are used to select arc-like candidates. The search was carried out in the <em>g</em> band which is the most efficient wavelength to find typical lensed features. This sample, called SARCS, has 55 promising and a total of 127 lens candidates which are selected from both CFHTLS Wide and Deep fields. The SARCS sample consists of some galaxy-scale candidates and mostly groups/cluster scale lens candidates. This is because more massive systems produce arcs or lensed images with large image separation from the lensing galaxy which are easier to detect compared to the galaxy scales. In the absence of a large systematically followed up verified sample of candidates, we choose the most promising 26 systems as our bona fide lens sample from the CFHTLS Wide. The total number of lens candidates in the CFHTLS Wide alone is 108.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Elyiv et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), the authors visually inspected a sample of 5500 optical counterparts of X-ray point-like sources identified in the <em>XMM</em>-LSS imaging of the CFHTLS <em>W</em>1 field. The goal was to find instances of lensed quasars. Their sample consists of a total of 18 candidates, of which 3 candidates were found to be promising.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gavazzi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) used their <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> code to find compact rings or arcs around centres of isolated and massive early-type galaxies. <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> subtracts the point spread function (PSF)-matched <em>i</em>-band images from the <em>g</em>-band images, and looks for excess flux in the bluer <em>g</em> band. An object detector measures the properties of these residual blue features, and candidates which meet the length\u2013width ratio and tangential alignment criteria are then visually inspected to form the final sample. Gavazzi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) pre-selected \u223c638\u00a0000 targets as either photometrically-classified early-type galaxies, or objects selected to have red centres and blue outer parts, from the T0006 CFHTLS data release catalogues. A total of 14\u00a0370 galaxies were found to show detectable blue residuals, and 2524 were visually inspected, having passed the automatic feature selection process. This led to a total of 330 lens candidates out of which 42 were deemed good quality (<span class=\"monospace\">q_flag</span>\u00a0=\u00a03) and 288 medium quality (<span class=\"monospace\">q_flag</span>\u00a0=\u00a02) candidates. In addition to the main well-defined sample of Gavazzi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), a further 71 candidates were reported to have been detected by earlier versions of the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span>, or from the CFHTLS Deep. From the main sample of \u2018<span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> candidates\u2019, the SL2S team found, during their follow-up campaign, 33 confirmed lenses (Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">a</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The work by Maturi, Mizera &amp; Seidel (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) used the arc-finding code of Seidel &amp; Bartelmann (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) and colour properties of typical arcs to optimize arc detection. This new approach was tested on the CFHTLS-Archive-Research Survey (Erben et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) which covers an area of 37\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> only, and this entire image set was also visually inspected by the authors to estimate the completeness and purity of their robotic search. They found 29 candidates with the robotic search alone and 41 candidates through pure visual inspection \u2013 some of which were known from previous searches. Most of these candidates are medium\u2013low probability.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> and the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> searches are the only searches that make use of a lens-finding algorithm and that have been run on the entire CFHTLS imaging data set. Thus, we considered these to be our reference sample of known lenses from robotic searches. For the purposes of transparency and to help with the training, the volunteers participating in S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>-CFHTLS lens search were made aware of these two known lens samples. Images containing the systems from the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> and the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> samples were labelled as \u2018known lens candidates\u2019 in the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> discussion forum, Talk,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> where volunteers have the opportunity to discuss their findings with fellow volunteers and the science team. In this paper, we refer to the sample of 330 <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> and 108 <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> lens candidates as the sample of \u2018known lens candidates\u2019 and the sample of confirmed (or most promising) 33 <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> and 26 <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> as the sample of \u2018known lenses\u2019. Note that the \u2018known lens\u2019 sample is a subset of the \u2018known lens candidates\u2019 sample. Also, note that the lens candidates from the other papers listed above were not included in our reference \u2018known\u2019 sample and were not labelled as such in Talk. However, we did exclude these candidates when compiling the list of new S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens candidates, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050540 id=\"92050540\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Image presentation in S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to perform a blind lens search over the entire CFHTLS Wide, we present the volunteers with cut-outs of images selected from the survey region. We briefly describe the image presentation here for completeness; more information can be found in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper I</a>. We use the <em>g</em>-, <em>r</em>- and <em>i</em>-band imaging from CFHTLS which is most useful for visual identification of lenses. We made colour composite images using the publicly available code, <span class=\"small-caps\">humvi</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>6</sup></a> following the prescription of Lupton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). The colour scales were chosen to maximize the contrast between faint extended objects and bright early-type galaxies. These parameters were then fixed during the production of all the tiles, in order to allow straightforward comparison between one image and another, and for intuition to be built up about the appearance of stars and galaxies across the survey.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We extracted contiguous cut-outs of size 82\u00a0arcsec (440\u00a0pixels), including overlapping region of 10\u00a0arcsec (54\u00a0pixels) between the neighbouring cut-outs. This resulted in a catalogue of some 430\u00a0000 cut-outs for the entire CFHTLS Wide region. The size of the individual cut-out was determined by optimizing factors such as the typical angular scales of gravitational lenses, the number of objects seen in a single cut-out and the total number of image cut-outs in the survey. If a lens candidate happens to be too close to the edge of a cut-out, then the overlap between neighbouring cut-outs allows a volunteer to get a clearer view of the same candidate in at least one of the cut-outs. We note that since the images are shown randomly, a volunteer may not necessarily come across the neighbouring cut-out unless they classify a large number of images. This is not a problem since our user base is extremely large and we receive multiple classifications for the same cut-out.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050543 id=\"92050543\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 TRAINING SAMPLE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The simulated lenses are important to train citizen scientists who may be new to the task of finding lenses, but they are also crucial for analysing the classifications performed by the citizen scientists (more details can be found in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper I</a>, but see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a> below for a brief summary). In this section, we describe the framework used for generating the simulated lens sample, give details of the sample itself along with some of its known limitations and also describe the sample of duds and impostors.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050545 id=\"92050545\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Methodology to simulate lenses</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For the purpose of generating simulated lens systems, we divide them into two main categories (a) galaxy-scale lenses (b) and group- or cluster-scale lenses. We further subdivide galaxy-scale lenses based on the type of the background sources, namely galaxies and quasars. We do not simulate group-scale quasar lenses as they are expected to be even more rare. We now describe our procedure to generate these different types of lens systems.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92050547 id=\"92050547\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-1>3.1.1 Galaxy-scale lenses</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We begin by considering all elliptical galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01 in our parent CFHTLS catalogue (Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) as potential lens candidates for the simulated sample. To avoid using a known lens galaxy for our simulation purpose, we exclude all those galaxies whose positions match with the lensing galaxies from the SARCS samples within 2 arcsec.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>7</sup></a></p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For each galaxy, the average number of source objects (either quasars or galaxies) above a minimum luminosity <em>L</em><sub>min</sub> in the background that may get lensed can be calculated as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nN_{\\rm src} = \\int _{z_{\\rm l}}^\\infty n_{\\rm src}(&gt;L_{\\rm min},z_{\\rm s}) \\sigma _{\\rm lens}(\\sigma _{\\rm v},z_{\\rm l},z_{\\rm s},q) \\frac{{\\rm d} V}{{\\rm d}z_{\\rm s}} {\\rm d}z_{\\rm s},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nn_{\\rm src}(&gt;L_{\\rm min},z_{\\rm s})= \\int _{L_{\\rm min}}^\\infty \\Phi (L^{\\prime },z_{\\rm s}) {\\rm d}L^{\\prime } \\,.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>Here, \u03a6(<em>L</em>\u2032, <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>) denotes the source luminosity function per unit comoving volume, \u03c3<sub>lens</sub> denotes the angular lens cross-section, which depends upon the lens redshift (<em>z</em><sub>l</sub>), source redshift (<em>z</em><sub>s</sub>), the lens velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub>v</sub> as well as the projected axis ratio of the lens ellipticity, <em>q</em>.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to calculate the lensing cross-section, we first calculate the luminosity of each potential lensing galaxy using the photometric redshifts (<em>z</em><sub>l</sub>) from the parent galaxy catalogue. Next, we use the <em>L</em>\u2013\u03c3 scaling relation from the bright sample of (Parker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\sigma _{\\rm v}=142 \\left(\\frac{L}{L_{*}}\\right)^{1/3} \\, {\\rm \\mathrm{km}\\ s^{-1}}.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>This sets the velocity dispersion of the halo hosting the galaxy, which will be later used in the model. We assume that the knee of the luminosity function of galaxies, <em>L</em><sub>*</sub> evolves such that there is a decline of 1.5 mag between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 to 0 (Faber et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>8</sup></a></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We adopt a singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE) model for each of our galaxies (Kormann, Schneider &amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>), such that the convergence is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\kappa (x,y) = \\frac{b \\sqrt{q}}{2}\\frac{1}{\\left( \\theta _1^2 + q^2\\theta _2^2\\right)^2} \\,.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>Here, <em>b</em> is called the Einstein radius, and its dependence on the velocity dispersion of the SIE is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nb = 4\\pi \\, \\left(\\frac{\\sigma _{\\rm v}^2}{c^2}\\right)\\left(\\frac{D_{\\rm {ls}}}{D_{\\rm s}}\\right) \\,.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>The SIE model results in a caustic and a pseudo-caustic on the source plane, which demarcates the regions of different image multiplicities. We make use of the parametric solutions, <em>r</em>\u2009(\u03b8), for the caustics in such a model from Keeton, Mao &amp; Witt (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000a</a>) where \u03b8 is the polar angle. We take the maximum of the radial and tangential caustic at every polar angle in order to obtain the area of the lensing cross-section, \u03c3<sub>lens</sub>, for every galaxy, <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\sigma _{\\rm lens}=\\frac{b^2 q}{2} \\, \\int _0^{2\\pi } r^2(\\theta ) \\mathrm{d}\\theta \\,.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>We also add external shear at the centre of the potential lensing galaxy drawn randomly from a set range (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). The shear is expected to affect the lens cross-section for a small number of cases when the shear strength is high in addition to high lens ellipticity or the position angle (PA) of the shear is almost orthogonal to that of the lens ellipticity. However, the effect of shear on the lens cross-section is expected to be small for most of the cases and is ignored in the current implementation of SIMCT.</div>                        <a id=\"92050552\" scrollto-destination=\"92050552\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thresholds used in the selection of the simulated lenses.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"2\">Gal\u2013Gal (Grp\u2013Gal)<span flux\u00a0</td><td>21.0\u00a0</td><td>25.5\u00a0</td><td>21.0\u00a0</td><td>25.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Source ellipticity\u00a0</td><td>0.1\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Source PA\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens redshift\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens shear strength\u00a0</td><td>0.001 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0.02 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0.001\u00a0</td><td>0.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens shear PA\u00a0</td><td>0 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>180 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Einstein radius (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td>1.2 (2)\u00a0</td><td>5 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>1.2\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Boost factor\u00a0</td><td>=100 (40)\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>=1200\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image flux<sub>2B</sub>\u00a0</td><td>&gt;23\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>&gt;23\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image flux<sub>tot</sub>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;19\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"2\">Gal\u2013Gal (Grp\u2013Gal)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"2\">Gal\u2013Qua<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Min<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Max<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Min<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Max<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Source redshift\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td><td>4.0\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td><td>5.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Source flux\u00a0</td><td>21.0\u00a0</td><td>25.5\u00a0</td><td>21.0\u00a0</td><td>25.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Source ellipticity\u00a0</td><td>0.1\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Source PA\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens redshift\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens shear strength\u00a0</td><td>0.001 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0.02 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0.001\u00a0</td><td>0.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens shear PA\u00a0</td><td>0 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>180 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Einstein radius (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td>1.2 (2)\u00a0</td><td>5 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>1.2\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Boost factor\u00a0</td><td>=100 (40)\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>=1200\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image flux<sub>2B</sub>\u00a0</td><td>&gt;23\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>&gt;23\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image flux<sub>tot</sub>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;19\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. (a) () corresponds to quantities used for Grp\u2013Gal scale lenses, if they are different from Gal\u2013Gal. (b) <sub>2B</sub> denotes the second brightest lensed image. (c) <sub>tot</sub> denotes the total flux integrated over all of the lensed images. (d) All fluxes are in AB mag. PA is in degrees measured east of north.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92050552\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thresholds used in the selection of the simulated lenses.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"2\">Gal\u2013Gal (Grp\u2013Gal)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"2\">Gal\u2013Qua<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Min<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Max<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Min<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Max<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Source redshift\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td><td>4.0\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td><td>5.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Source flux\u00a0</td><td>21.0\u00a0</td><td>25.5\u00a0</td><td>21.0\u00a0</td><td>25.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Source ellipticity\u00a0</td><td>0.1\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Source PA\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens redshift\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens shear strength\u00a0</td><td>0.001 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0.02 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0.001\u00a0</td><td>0.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens shear PA\u00a0</td><td>0 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>180 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Einstein radius (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td>1.2 (2)\u00a0</td><td>5 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>1.2\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Boost factor\u00a0</td><td>=100 (40)\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>=1200\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image flux<sub>2B</sub>\u00a0</td><td>&gt;23\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>&gt;23\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image flux<sub>tot</sub>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;19\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"2\">Gal\u2013Gal (Grp\u2013Gal)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"2\">Gal\u2013Qua<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Min<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Max<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Min<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Max<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Source redshift\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td><td>4.0\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td><td>5.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Source flux\u00a0</td><td>21.0\u00a0</td><td>25.5\u00a0</td><td>21.0\u00a0</td><td>25.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Source ellipticity\u00a0</td><td>0.1\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Source PA\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens redshift\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens shear strength\u00a0</td><td>0.001 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0.02 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0.001\u00a0</td><td>0.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Lens shear PA\u00a0</td><td>0 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>180 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>180\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Einstein radius (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td>1.2 (2)\u00a0</td><td>5 (\u2013)\u00a0</td><td>1.2\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Boost factor\u00a0</td><td>=100 (40)\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>=1200\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image flux<sub>2B</sub>\u00a0</td><td>&gt;23\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>&gt;23\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image flux<sub>tot</sub>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;19\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. (a) () corresponds to quantities used for Grp\u2013Gal scale lenses, if they are different from Gal\u2013Gal. (b) <sub>2B</sub> denotes the second brightest lensed image. (c) <sub>tot</sub> denotes the total flux integrated over all of the lensed images. (d) All fluxes are in AB mag. PA is in degrees measured east of north.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92050552\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The luminosity functions of the background galaxies and quasars are determined as follows. We use the results of Faure et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) to specify the luminosity function of galaxies where the redshift distribution of sources is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ7\" content-id=\"equ7\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\np_{\\rm s}=\\frac{\\beta z_{\\rm s}^2 {\\rm exp}({\\frac{z_{\\rm s}}{z_0(m_{\\rm lim})}})^\\beta }{\\Gamma (3/\\beta )z_0^3(m_{\\rm lim})},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(7)</span></div>where \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a03/2 and <em>z</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>m</em><sub>lim</sub>)\u00a0=\u00a00.13<em>m</em><sub>lim</sub> \u2212 2.2 and the source counts as a function of the limiting magnitude are given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ8\" content-id=\"equ8\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nn_{\\rm s}=\\int ^{m_{\\rm lim}}_{-\\infty } \\frac{n_0 {\\rm d}m}{\\sqrt{10^{2a(m_1-m)}+10^{2b(m_1-m)}}} \\,,\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(8)</span></div>with parameters <em>a</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.30, <em>b</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.56, <em>m</em><sub>1</sub>\u00a0=\u00a020 and <em>n</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a03\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>3</sup>\u2009deg<sup>\u22122</sup>.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For quasars, we assume the luminosity function prescription of Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and adopt <em>k</em>-corrections by Richards et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The luminosity function is expressed as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ9\" content-id=\"equ9\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\frac{{\\rm d}\\Phi }{{\\rm d}M}=\\frac{\\Phi _{*}}{10^{0.4(\\alpha +1)(M_{\\rm abs}-M_{*})} + 10^{0.4(\\beta +1)(M_{\\rm abs}-M_{*})} },\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(9)</span></div>where the normalization, \u03d5<sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a05.34\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22126</sup><em>h</em><sup>3</sup>\u00a0Mpc<sup>\u22123</sup> and break magnitude, <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221220.90\u00a0+\u00a05log<em>h</em> \u2212 2.5log\u2009<em>f</em>(<em>z</em>). The redshift-dependent factor in <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ10\" content-id=\"equ10\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nf(z)=\\frac{\\mathrm{e}^{\\zeta z_{\\rm s}}(1+\\mathrm{e}^{\\xi z_*})}{(\\sqrt{\\mathrm{e}^{\\xi z_{\\rm s}}}+\\sqrt{\\mathrm{e}^{\\xi z_*}})^2} \\,.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(10)</span></div>We adopt the best-fitting values \u03b6\u00a0=\u00a02.98, \u03be\u00a0=\u00a04.05, <em>z</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.60 (Oguri &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). For the faint end slope, we use \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121.45 whereas for the bright end slope, we use \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a0\u22123.31 when <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a03 and \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a0\u22122.58 at higher redshifts, as prescribed by Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">With the cross-section, and the luminosity functions specified, we calculate the expected number of sources behind a candidate lensing galaxy using equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>). We need to generate a large number of simulated lenses (larger than the number of real galaxy lenses we expect to find in CFHTLS) in order to have a reasonably large and diverse training sample for thousands of S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> volunteers. Therefore, we artificially boost the average number of sources by a factor (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), which increases the occurrence of lensing. We draw a Poisson deviate, <em>N</em><sub>src</sub> with a mean equal to the boosted average number of sources. If <em>N</em><sub>src</sub> is greater than zero, then this galaxy is flagged as a potential lensing galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Next, we determine properties of the background sources for every lens system. We follow similar procedures for both background galaxies and quasars. We draw source redshifts and luminosities from the aforementioned distributions. We note that the sources are being drawn from a much fainter magnitude range compared to the limiting magnitude of the CFHTLS imaging and thus, the magnification bias<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn9\" data-open=\"fn9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>9</sup></a> is naturally taken into account. The source positions with respect to the lens are drawn randomly from an area inside the caustic. When populating the sources within the caustics, the finite size of the background galaxies is expected to affect the lens cross-sections to some extent. As this factor is not critical for the purpose of our training sample, for simplicity we assume the background galaxies to be point like when computing cross-sections. We perform ray-tracing for all of the <em>N</em><sub>src</sub> sources using the publicly available code <span class=\"small-caps\">gravlens</span> (Keeton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000b</a>) and choose sources that satisfy our selection criteria given below. We determine the fluxes of the lensed images and the total magnification of each of the lensed sources. We draw a source randomly for which the flux of the second brightest lensed image and the total magnification of all lensed images meet the thresholds given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Since we want to produce realistic looking lens systems, we simulate lenses in each of the five CFHTLS filters. The colours of the background galaxies are drawn randomly from the photometric CFHTLenS catalogue (Hildebrandt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Erben et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Similarly, we use a quasar catalogue from the SDSS Data Release 9 (P\u00e2ris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) from which colours are drawn to simulate quasar lenses. Next, we assume a Gaussian profile<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn10\" data-open=\"fn10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>10</sup></a> for the galaxies. The ellipticity and the PA are drawn randomly from within the range given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The effective radius of the galaxy is estimated from the luminosity\u2013size relation (Bernardi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>, with a redshift scaling, to account for size evolution) given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ11\" content-id=\"equ11\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nR_{\\rm eff}= 10^{0.52} \\frac{L_r^{2/3}}{{(1+z_{\\rm s})}^2} \\, {\\rm kpc},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(11)</span></div>where <em>L</em><sub><em>r</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>L</em><sub>s</sub>/10<sup>10.2</sup>\u2009L<sub>\u2299</sub>. On the other hand, quasars are assumed to be point sources and the PSF, with which quasars are convolved, is assumed to have a Gaussian profile. The full width at half-maximum of the PSF is equated to that of the mean seeing for every filter. The mean seeing values are taken from table 4 of the official <span class=\"small-caps\">terapix</span> T0007 release explanatory document (see footnote 3).</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Once all the parameters are determined for the lens and source models, we once again use <span class=\"small-caps\">gravlens</span> to generate simulated lensed images. After accounting for the shot noise in the lensed images and convolving them with the seeing in each of the filters, the simulated image is added to the real CFHTLS image centred on the galaxy chosen to act as a lens (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). Note that we ensure that the lensed galaxies and lensed quasars are not superposed on the same \u2018lensing\u2019 galaxy. Similarly, these \u2018lensing\u2019 galaxies at the galaxy scales are ensured to be distinct from those chosen for the group scales. The framework for the group scale is described below.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92050560 id=\"92050560\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-2>3.1.2 Group-scale lenses</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">At group or cluster scales, the mass distribution is more complex. The convergence in the inner regions, which are typically responsible for the multiple lensed images, arises from not only the brightest group galaxy (BGG) at the centre, but also from the dark matter component and the satellite galaxies (Oguri, Keeton &amp; Dalal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). We generate a basic group catalogue based on the magnitudes and photometric redshifts available for the CFHTLS. We select all galaxies with 10<sup>10.8</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> as plausible BGGs. We select the member galaxies such that their photometric redshifts are within \u03b4<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.01 of the BGG and within an aperture of 250\u00a0kpc. If another BGG is found within the aperture, then the fainter BGG is removed from our list of BGGs.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We assume a constant mass-to-light ratio of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a00.7\u2009<em>h</em>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>*</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>*</sub>, to convert the BGG luminosity to a stellar mass estimate. The stellar mass\u2013halo mass relation (Behroozi, Wechsler &amp; Conroy <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), including random scatter, is then used to calculate the halo mass for the lens. We adopt an NFW (Navarro, Frenk &amp; White <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>) density profile for the underlying dark matter halo. Given the halo mass, other key parameters such as the scale radius (<em>r</em><sub>s</sub>) and the density at the scale radius (\u03c1<sub>s</sub>) can be determined for an NFW profile. In addition, we adopt an SIE model for the BGG and members whenever the ellipticities are available from the galaxy catalogue (else we use an isothermal sphere, SIS).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We calculate the luminosities and velocity dispersions for the BGG and each of the member galaxies following the same prescription as in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1.1</a>. To calculate the average number of sources that get lensed by such a system, we need to calculate the lensing cross-section for each of these potential lensing groups. The complexity in the lens models makes it analytically intractable to calculate the size of the caustics.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn11\" data-open=\"fn11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>11</sup></a> Therefore, we generate the caustics numerically using <span class=\"small-caps\">gravlens</span> and then determine the area covered by the caustics. We consider only galaxies as our background source population since group- or cluster-scale quasar lenses are expected to be extremely rare in the CFHTLS. Following the same procedure as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1.1</a>, we calculate the number of galaxies expected to lie behind every potential lensing group (see equation\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>). As before, for each background galaxy within the lens cross-section, a redshift and an <em>i</em>-band magnitude is determined by drawing galaxies randomly from the respective distributions (see equations\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ7\"></span><a href=\"#equ7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ8\"></span><a href=\"#equ8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">8</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All those groups that are found to have no background galaxies within the cross-sectional area are rejected and the rest are included as potential lenses. As mentioned earlier, we artificially boost the total number of sources behind every lens but ensure that the statistical properties such as the profile of the image separation distribution are not affected (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). We follow the same procedure and apply thresholds to determine properties of the lensed galaxies for every lens as described for galaxy\u2014galaxy lenses in the previous section. The thresholds are same as those used for galaxy lenses (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) and are reported within \u2018()\u2019, if different for group scales. The simulated lensed images are then added to the real CFHTLS images with the BGGs as the centre by following exactly the same procedure as described in the previous section (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p>                        <a (2012).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050566/stv1965fig2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050566\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=IbrkShADHlX~QxWXz3tDPmEXPHORdJhJact7WsZ7po0a73mucWYtIVm23QuUJcXmgkIPkVRXRbdG4UbHJqnohrz0ZWUpqNsn0Pm0lk4tlIWj5Lk7LcXW7pDEaAnU2w0FVu6xpQitKfCW~VVFT1NoFiBdqi8EFO9yHTniXeeHVPZPSm19bLssPtFf87KJ7~HDcsqhvzoduCtoYwyVm4EodUItLbYgLMsCLWAVa1hsnd35icaaQtXvdHRPADRwPSE3-AS5t5zgZWVWutct~H48PqPHjO8nnVUOeGpcBqEYQGwQ~JG8V-mPB5lbIgcOS-aHcirxfrcVbxFTQk~LfkuACA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050566&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Einstein radius and total magnification distributions for all types of lenses. The solid (blue) curves show the theoretical prediction assuming an SIS model at galaxy scales and a total (NFW+Hernquist) model at group scales taken from More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050567 id=\"92050567\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Simulated lens sample and catalogue description</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we describe some of the properties of our simulated sample for each of the three types of lens samples. We have made an attempt to generate as realistic a lens sample as possible within the requirements of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> project. The statistical properties of the lens sample are expected to be similar to real lens samples.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we show the Einstein radius (<em>R</em><sub>E</sub>) distribution for the galaxy-scale and group-scale simulated lenses. For comparison, we give the expected distributions (blue solid curves) for an SIS (singular isothermal sphere) like density profile at galaxy scales and an NFW+Hernquist profile at group scales. The theoretical curves are taken from More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) wherein the models are explained in detail. We note that the model we adopt at the group scale also includes SIS or SIE components for the group members unlike the theoretical prediction. The theoretical curves have arbitrary normalizations. We also show the distribution of the total magnification for all three samples.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Next, we consider the redshift, magnitude and ellipticity distributions of the \u2018lensing\u2019 galaxies from the simulated sample as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. For reference, we also show SARCS lenses from More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), with arbitrary normalizations. We find that the properties of the foreground lenses in the simulated and the real lens samples are broadly similar.</p>                        <a id=\"92050571\" \u2018lensing\u2019 galaxies of the simulated sample compared to the known lens sample SARCS.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\"
