class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distributions of properties of the \u2018lensing\u2019 galaxies of the simulated sample compared to the known lens sample SARCS.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=UsbhhDMLepffhVNiyUr~sGeh-4x047AFJd59d-PbqeQgEYrma40OYLaGvu55icK24joH9OSWv5D418QBAQyNcIXK4nZDRRCzpY156X-ndxN1uaxc5Ly1YebrB3bste5xh8IJ0UciV3nZTpHh7tnCYT9VEJrrlJ64bmYbyc3uFjOlvetbvV8DEc1t6mTWzWkkIOySMhMR5MflsHSKwDrRswqUoz~FuvcbBnu3MpIbMQJdxDDYY0CVbLQX~urnnauxj-EEj02Wj-v4kqBPTgyqqgOb4T0oqdImfRN51Nizrh3ROxmfnI0L~RZU-Y3iycvnisGuQTx9P30JDpdGzvJzRA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distributions of properties of the \u2018lensing\u2019 galaxies of the simulated sample compared to the known lens sample SARCS.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050571/stv1965fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050571\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=vhYYsvoFQ62yOk8dUcfCOSMnDTmPDpzlpxyzDtbDVewASOpCwo~XLU8CGwnGSuQvpU4Av-6EkvF-eKSrsMQMrAtDKm~9lAR4gTd-O4SzXUmSaNdZbTyVyChHuc2aHVfjPoTuLDs5nnKI7FynOT8n8bXPDrbD0jhvefwKu2t5IfmAunaZtJr~AMIj04PoL4KQUk~03hkQcB~c7va5KcH7kR1axNfqFO6oQgo2agzHbAD2XInrMbSMxp6m7Zwr09HcXuvZbf3HOwUKMgwkAcIVHWwZUapNa9HA0qiXUgWrY05JDwoLLbOAqA~WFsjLFgZaptPAsZ-k2bvzfXGA9TTJ6Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050571&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distributions of properties of the \u2018lensing\u2019 galaxies of the simulated sample compared to the known lens sample SARCS.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We produce catalogues with lens and source properties for each of the three types of simulated lenses. The catalogues typically have lens position, redshift, magnitudes, Einstein radius, ellipticity (whenever available) and shear (for galaxy-scale lenses only). For the background sources, we provide the offset from the lens centre, redshift, magnitudes, total magnification, number of lensed images. Additionally, when possible, ellipticity and effective radius of the background galaxies have also been provided. These catalogues are available from <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/anupreeta27/SIMCT\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/anupreeta27/SIMCT</a> and the simulated lens image sample is available from the authors on request.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050573 id=\"92050573\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Limitations of the simulated lens sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The simulated lens sample, although realistic, is not perfect, due to the simplicity of the lensing models and our limited understanding of the uncertainties in the model parameters. Comments from citizen scientists were very helpful in order to identify some of these failures, which make up roughly 5\u2009per\u2009cent of the simulated sample.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn12\" data-open=\"fn12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>12</sup></a> Here, we describe some of the cases or aspects in which the simulations were known to have failed to look realistic.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The parameters required by the models\u2019 various scaling relations primarily depend on the photometry of the galaxies, groups and quasars detected in the survey. For galaxy-scale lenses, the fainter or higher redshift galaxies, chosen to act as lenses, tend to have poor photometric redshift measurements. Consequently these galaxies were occasionally assigned the wrong luminosity and velocity dispersion estimates, resulting in simulated lenses which look implausible or unrealistic. For example, the lensed images for some of the failed simulations have larger image separation than what one would expect from the luminosity and/or size of the galaxy. We roughly expect mass to follow light, so more massive galaxies typically look brighter and/or bigger.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">At group scales, the magnitudes and photometric redshifts were used when defining the group membership. Therefore, errors in redshift estimates occasionally generated galaxy groups having member galaxies with unrealistically dissimilar properties. In some cases, low-redshift spiral galaxies were incorrectly assigned high redshift. Spiral galaxies are typically less massive and low-redshift spiral galaxies are unlikely to act as gravitational lenses. Hence, some such instances did not appear convincing, as the lensed images again did not have the expected configurations or separations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also use a single component to describe the light distribution of the background galaxies. This is clearly not the most accurate description for galaxies, especially for the irregular star-forming galaxies which comprise a significant fraction of the lensed galaxy population. Star-forming galaxies have complex structures such as star-forming knots, spiral arms, bars and discs. The simulated lensed images do not display these features. This is not problematic for most of the images taken from ground-based telescopes such as the CFHT but sometimes the profiles of the lensed arcs can appear very symmetric (along the length or width of the arc) and featureless, especially, if the images are very bright.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050578 id=\"92050578\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Duds and impostors</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Citizen scientists need training not only to identify gravitational lenses, but also to reject images which either contain no lenses, or contain objects which could be mistaken for lenses. Hence, in addition to the simulated lenses, we added a sample of \u2018duds\u2019 and \u2018impostors\u2019 to the training sample. Duds are images which have been visually inspected by experts and confirmed to contain no lenses. Impostors are systems which have lens like features but are not lenses in reality, for example, spiral galaxies, star-forming galaxies, chance alignments of features arranged in a lensing configuration and stars.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We selected a sample of 450 duds for the Stage 1 classification in S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> and a sample of 500 impostors for the Stage 2 inspection. The sample of impostors was selected from the candidates who passed the Stage 1 of S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>. We note that this is the first time we have a systematically compiled sample of visually inspected impostors by the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> volunteers and categorized by the science team. We produced an additional larger sample of a few thousand false positive detections by scanning through the low-probability images after the completion of Stage 2. All of these data products will be made available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://spacewarps.org/#/projects/CFHTLS/\" target=\"_blank\">http://spacewarps.org/#/projects/CFHTLS/</a>. Such a sample has tremendous utility for training and testing of various lens-finding algorithms (e.g. Chan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050581 id=\"92050581\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 METHODOLOGY TO PRODUCE THE S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>-CFHTLS LENS SAMPLE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> works as a single unified system which uses the method of visual inspection to find gravitational lenses. For the first S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens search, the volunteers were shown images at two stages. At Stage 1, volunteers were asked to carry out a rapid inspection to select lens candidates ranging from possible lenses to almost certain lenses. At Stage 2, volunteers were asked to inspect the candidates from Stage 1 and select only promising lens candidates. A daily snapshot of the classifications performed by volunteers was provided to the science team every night. This daily batch was analysed by the Space Warps Analysis Pipeline (SWAP). The philosophy and the details of SWAP are described in detail in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper I</a>. Here, we briefly summarize how it works.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each subject (image cut-out) is assigned a prior probability of 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup> of containing a lens system. Every volunteer is assigned an agent characterized by a 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02 confusion matrix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\bf{M}$|\u2060</span>, which quantifies the volunteer's ability to correctly classify an image as containing a lens (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\bf{M}_{\\mathrm{LL}}= P_\\mathrm{L}$|\u2060</span>) or not containing a lens (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\bf{M}_{\\mathrm{NN}}= P_\\mathrm{D}$|\u2060</span>). The values of these confusion matrix elements are determined based on the performance of the volunteer on the training sample, specifically, <em>P</em><sub>L</sub> (and <em>P</em><sub>D</sub>) is determined based on the fraction of simulated lenses (and, respectively, duds) correctly classified. After every classification, the agent updates the probability of the classified subject based on the volunteer's classification and the confusion matrix, according to Bayes\u2019 theorem. The agent's confusion matrix is updated after the classification of every training image. The thresholds for the probabilities to accept or reject a subject if it contains a lens or does not contain one can be chosen in SWAP. In Stage 1, those images which cross these threshold values are \u2018retired\u2019, and are not subsequently shown to the volunteers. In this way, the crowd can use its time efficiently in inspecting previously unclassified subjects.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SWAP was run nightly during Stage 1 in order to retire subjects and inject new ones in to the classification stream. The subjects that passed the detection threshold at the end of Stage 1 were served again at Stage 2 for careful re-inspection. The goal of Stage 1 inspection was to maximize completeness and that of Stage 2 was to maximize purity. Each subject, after Stage 2, has a final posterior probability <em>P</em>. In the ideal case, all images containing lenses will have high <em>P</em> values and those without lenses will have low <em>P</em> values. In practice, we expect a small fraction of the real lenses (or non-lenses) to be assigned low (or high) <em>P</em> values, thereby decreasing the completeness (or purity) of the final lens sample. As this is the first lens search with S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>, we want to find a threshold <em>P</em> value which will result in acceptable levels of completeness and purity of the final sample of lens candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To achieve this, we selected a total of 665 subjects with <em>P</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.3 at Stage 2 which were then visually inspected by three of us (as \u2018lens experts\u2019, AM, AV, PJM). Each image was assigned a grade on a scale of 0\u20133, representing those images: 0 \u2013 unlikely to contain a lens; 1 \u2013 possibly containing a lens; 2 \u2013 probably containing a lens; and 3 \u2013 almost certainly containing a lens. The final sample of S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>-CFHTLS lens candidates was then produced by selecting candidates above a threshold on the averaged grade <em>G</em>, as described in the next section.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050586 id=\"92050586\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 RESULTS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050587 id=\"92050587\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>-CFHTLS lens sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we describe the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> candidate lens sample from the CFHTLS. We find a total of 141 candidates with <em>G</em>\u00a0\u2265\u00a01.3 (medium\u2013high grade), of which 59 are new systems. This sample is further divided as follows. We have a total of 50 candidates with 1.3\u00a0\u2264\u00a0<em>G</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a02 (medium grade), of which 30 are new. The quality of candidates in this category is such that at least one of the inspectors (\u2018lens expert\u2019) thought the candidate was probably a lens (that is, a grade of 2) and a second inspector thought that it was possibly a lens (that is, a grade of 1). Among our high-grade sample (<em>G</em>\u00a0\u2265\u00a02), there are a total of 91 candidates, of which 29 are new. In this category, the minimum grade by all of the inspectors was 2, suggesting that the candidates are probably or almost certainly lenses according to all three inspectors. To avoid duplication, only the newly discovered lens candidates with <em>G</em>\u22651.3 (medium\u2013high probability) are presented in this paper (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2</a>), and further information on S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>-selected candidates that were previously identified in the literature (as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>) will be made available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://spacewarps.org/#/projects/CFHTLS/\" target=\"_blank\">http://spacewarps.org/#/projects/CFHTLS/</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also find a total of 288 (and 245 new) candidates with averaged grade 0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>G</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.3 (low grade), which means that at least one of the inspector thought the candidate was possibly a lens, and in the best cases, all three inspectors thought the candidate was possibly a lens (that is, a grade of 1).<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn13\" data-open=\"fn13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>13</sup></a> Further information on the low-probability sample such as their positions and images will be available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://spacewarps.org/#/projects/CFHTLS/\" target=\"_blank\">http://spacewarps.org/#/projects/CFHTLS/</a>. Note that if all of the inspectors gave a grade of 0 to a candidate, then it was discarded from the sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we give overall statistics of the systems detected at Stage 1 and Stage 2. We give the total number of detections of the known lens candidates, known lenses and the new lens candidates at each stage. We also give the recovery fractions for the known samples and fraction of total detection for the new samples at each stage. Overall, the sample of new S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens candidates comprises over 40\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the total S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> -CFHTLS lens candidates. We find that 90\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the confirmed lenses found at Stage 1 are also recovered at Stage 2. However, \u223c35\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the known lenses were missed already at Stage 1: we return to the discussion of these false negatives below in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.3</a>. Nearly 45\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the known lens candidates from Stage 1 are rejected at Stage 2. Such fractions are acceptable for \u2018candidates\u2019 as their quality grades vary from high to low.</p>                        <a id=\"92050591\" scrollto-destination=\"92050591\"></a>\r\n<div are selected</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN007\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN007\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>) whereas for NC and AC, percentages are with respect to the total sample of 429 lens candidates.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA; content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em> KC\u2013 Known lens candidates</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">KL\u2013 Known lenses</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">NC\u2013 New lens candidates</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN005\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN005\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">AC\u2013 All (known and new) lens candidates</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN006\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN006\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>P</em><sub>accthresh</sub> \u2013 systems with posterior probability <em>P</em> above this threshold are selected</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN007\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN007\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. For KC and KL, percentages are with respect to the known population (i.e. 438 KC and 59 KL; see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>) whereas for NC and AC, percentages are with respect to the total sample of 429 lens candidates.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92050591\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, we plot the distribution of false positives and the high-grade lens candidates, as a function of the <em>P</em> value assigned by SWAP at the end of Stage 2. On average, the fraction of lens candidates is indeed an increasing function of <em>P</em>. This shows that the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> generated <em>P</em> values for the subject are roughly correlated with the expert grades albeit with quite some scatter. We note that below <em>P</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.75, the fraction of false positives starts to exceed the fraction of real lens candidates. This could be a good threshold to choose to maximize the purity of the final sample. However, choosing <em>P</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.3 gives a completeness of 92\u2009per\u2009cent for the \u2018known lens\u2019 sample instead of 64\u2009per\u2009cent for <em>P</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.75. Therefore, the new sample should also have increased completeness; expert grading then allows us to increase the purity of the sample.</p>                        <a id=\"92050593\" scrollto-destination=\"92050593\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=O376SKfdyWoLmwBXPveGpTjfnpFW79W8IzaGr~EdeLohzYNQCg8LDi~f0mhov3~bvBXIl1lk1RLZtlhsLg2s0bSKWUwQLzQdtp1WfK5ziRD2Xc1W2KtR6gYi-QnWAcsEpVtqwC3BlssHRDrULNoGTl1KMYyJ5cD5F6H61xufYcx5msHz30cxXTxEbGS5XIWM8~QjOtrROwJkGC2eMyq4S85sxiVqyGGyBNYmStwv0J-ylKqlrcYZ5vlksn9kAIpbmyCFiT6Cj5ewd-oxh-7gdc2NLndkWVvI71AiQYnJPeJSCRQx70HWmqApP87gI8djfAEKDVXyqOBIl~bZr~6adA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of different types of candidates as a function of the posterior probability P, obtained at the end of Stage 2. The new and known candidates have higher detection rate for higher values of P, as expected.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050593/stv1965fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050593\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=2vYQVXXnLqWuvczgoN1RnjnmEsl5eNVwglBKVUEQuu5Yfk~-7h4XO3yC-XYDNvlIYYH8pTTgFnwzheIpNLf3mYRM6vH3yAZ9Xe5CdoaFLdxzbS36NBhNGGZUFlI~-sxAEe0SHqkoE73l5Mgjtwgw5cyLcXuancIRibwNxbjBDS0MgSmgAcziISsayUjfVTTfQvJygDnK49fYCAOXm7wh3idn9Q4eIIa4xXx6F04DgNGZYfFBBmiHvYzwu60TI8MHhXithiIUX8FGbJkK6facFNuIEpq5JOCAVELsAdLWk5nnUmEjgubR52F5e3fIiT65pRUt0qlrwJuVy2T1dr1NQg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050593&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of different types of candidates as a function of the posterior probability <em>P</em>, obtained at the end of Stage 2. The types of the candidates are the false positives (FPs), the new candidates and the known candidates. The new and known candidates have higher detection rate for higher values of <em>P</em>, as expected.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050594 id=\"92050594\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 New lens candidates from S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We give basic information about the final sample of 59 new medium\u2013high grade lens candidates found by S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. We report the candidates with a S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> ID and Name of the lens system. We give their positions (RA, Dec), photometric redshift (<em>z</em><sub>phot</sub>), <em>i</em>-band magnitude of the lensing galaxy, averaged grade <em>G</em> from the lens experts, zoo ID (identifier used in TALK), <em>P</em> value at Stage 2 and a visual categorization of the type of lensed images and the lensing galaxy in the \u2018Comments\u2019 column in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. Whenever available the lens properties are taken from the CFHTLS photometric catalogue (Coupon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>); otherwise, for the lens galaxy positions, the reported values were measured manually. The visual categorization of the lens type is only suggestive and the explanation of the notations in the Comments column is given at the bottom of the table.</p>                        <a id=\"92050596\" scrollto-destination=\"92050596\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN008\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN008\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. The column Comments has two type of notes. The first is about the lens image configuration where the symbols mean the following A: arc, D: double, Q: quad, R: ring. The second is a comment on the type of lens assessed visually. Note that this classification is not based on colours or spectral analysis. The symbols are E: elliptical, S: (face on) spiral, G: group-scale, D: edge-on disc, R: red star-forming galaxy.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN008\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN008\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. The column Comments has two type of notes. The first is about the lens image configuration where the symbols mean the following A: arc, D: double, Q: quad, R: ring. The second is a comment on the type of lens assessed visually. Note that this classification is not based on colours or spectral analysis. The symbols are E: elliptical, S: (face on) spiral, G: group-scale, D: edge-on disc, R: red star-forming galaxy.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92050596\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We show images of our new sample in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5a\" data-open=\"fig5a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. The panels are arranged first in the descending order of their grades, and within each grade, in ascending order of RA. As the first lens search was a blind search with no pre-selection of candidates from any algorithm, we find various types of lenses, as expected from such a search. The final sample consists of both galaxy- and group-scale lens candidates. There are detections of elongated arcs and some interesting point-like quasar lensed images. Most of them are brighter in the bluer <em>g</em> band, but some candidates brighter in the redder <em>i</em> band are also found. Since the robotic lens searches focused on the blue lensed features, they are likely to miss such interesting lens candidates. We did not find any examples of exotic lens candidates from the visually inspected <em>P</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.3 sample. There may be some more interesting candidates that were missed either at Stage 1 or Stage 2 but have been identified by volunteers in Talk. This resource is yet to be mined and is left for future work.</p>                        <a id=\"92050598\" scrollto-destination=\"92050598\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5a\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig5a.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=dLxjVOX3DPGP5m75dglOtYWJmlDafaUBpeBugjyBUGRuzlcd1tD94-uLgHRG9n~H~YyOm8wwip1aBhVyz3iLy~gykiVSQ9dlJva2NDTepHYztlrTaK9NBsqDxihQxQ6cEYF85lCPxOrTwZ1muTF4fSlvtm1Ks5w~-EmjOkPz5YPCzJddLz10FzpeTmI5-EPelMIknO50YC7R-9CRxQsolIKXygHSvmgB3un4SxvHOECGz9mjU8FL-507EYXARQTvYPkrUfpNqJer4KmLUirSVvMTC79YI1SwfvEfgc02lxHshsz9zpUGsK-1W67cfJBRrblS9c0cjXIEsi1pl92aMQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The new Space\u00a0Warps lens candidates with expert grade G&gt;=1.3. The images are 30\u00a0arcsec on the side.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"92050599\" scrollto-destination=\"92050599\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5b\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig5b.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=zc6sddkp6cuokJatUYLUKn8i6BkyUVWxaJJr2I0N8HzY-1TZSNvYSbW2fSkIAZwWf3ap2Mi~t5WsadxcOjwwI3ehh3KM-6zZmIiM2~Q7-8v~fjtGpblHr7-rZjl1uqdGniANKInHU7ahQ3ND4YVWp4gwHkhGD9gu9JveohLMv7JB-fx0H5lzak5ov2KiIfW7kkdamOfLB37BvopKK2V~PLxzMOIDFA1xyfWV0Jx2ZgQZznMStxVVoTI6jHpomj8njEGKENnrz6bXNuotBwOWkbfrW7FmwMrq2WF3z59aOVUNFcIIhyFJJtcgUI10Lz500ZEMjLoKq7OxCSvTl9SMnA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"\u2013\u2002continued.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig5b.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050599/stv1965fig5b.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig5b.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050599\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig5b.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=b57uzCDBuzvh5gsiygs3~sT6rfxDmRPSxQCCarnUGH~z6Ec346eOG0gO9Uv-p4aUbQm4fc4R8MSU5OH2bzcCAKBpDo4qzqt6Eo4kFbzLsPKX4D7cWDzrcwOqNMsbqRBqVuavHpjeiT~XWDFmo6LNmvNXT-ggfWAsnpliKdVyW7zKQTmxFVkeS0bkp2wj98270PtGpGBgg4P7kOm852eaDDof-C9Wrwzwp0sbmRkBqmpTJyX9PgoDi83FBXJNFH59NOj6eUe5dyFboTh5QlJhhoJTIg0uujmSdovu1OKvMWfx-QiV~CC5hnBZnBTRruDlBqm9lBBkjgvPt5yVXn-9CA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050599&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig5b.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>\u2013\u2002continued</em>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5b\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig5b.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=zc6sddkp6cuokJatUYLUKn8i6BkyUVWxaJJr2I0N8HzY-1TZSNvYSbW2fSkIAZwWf3ap2Mi~t5WsadxcOjwwI3ehh3KM-6zZmIiM2~Q7-8v~fjtGpblHr7-rZjl1uqdGniANKInHU7ahQ3ND4YVWp4gwHkhGD9gu9JveohLMv7JB-fx0H5lzak5ov2KiIfW7kkdamOfLB37BvopKK2V~PLxzMOIDFA1xyfWV0Jx2ZgQZznMStxVVoTI6jHpomj8njEGKENnrz6bXNuotBwOWkbfrW7FmwMrq2WF3z59aOVUNFcIIhyFJJtcgUI10Lz500ZEMjLoKq7OxCSvTl9SMnA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"\u2013\u2002continued.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig5b.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050599/stv1965fig5b.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig5b.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050599\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig5b.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=b57uzCDBuzvh5gsiygs3~sT6rfxDmRPSxQCCarnUGH~z6Ec346eOG0gO9Uv-p4aUbQm4fc4R8MSU5OH2bzcCAKBpDo4qzqt6Eo4kFbzLsPKX4D7cWDzrcwOqNMsbqRBqVuavHpjeiT~XWDFmo6LNmvNXT-ggfWAsnpliKdVyW7zKQTmxFVkeS0bkp2wj98270PtGpGBgg4P7kOm852eaDDof-C9Wrwzwp0sbmRkBqmpTJyX9PgoDi83FBXJNFH59NOj6eUe5dyFboTh5QlJhhoJTIg0uujmSdovu1OKvMWfx-QiV~CC5hnBZnBTRruDlBqm9lBBkjgvPt5yVXn-9CA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050599&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig5b.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>\u2013\u2002continued</em>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The new S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens sample presented here illustrates some of the advantages of having citizen scientists find lenses through visual inspection. An algorithm, by definition will find objects that adhere to a selection criteria that uses either geometry or flux information from an image. On the other hand, citizen scientists can interpolate over or extrapolate beyond the basic selection criteria provided to them. For example, the lower blue arc in SW7 is split by a small red galaxy. An algorithm typically fails to detect such arcs because the arc is broken into smaller arclets which then falls below the minimum length or area allowed for an arc to be detected. Human inspectors have no problem in interpolating over the broken blue arc over the red galaxy, understanding that it is a single long arc. The system SW20 has point-like lensed images which cannot be detected by arc-finding algorithm, whereas the ring-finding algorithm may have missed this because of the atypical colour and structure of the lensing galaxy. Detection of red arcs, for example, as seen in the SW39 candidate, shows how the volunteers extrapolate on the colour parameter: the training sample contains predominantly blue arcs, because the source colours were drawn from realistic observed distributions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The power of citizen scientists also lies in the high dynamic range that allows us to find systems which have very short (thick) to long (thin) arcs, from highly compact to low surface brightness images, from round and point-like to elongated and curved images, from blue to red, from regular to exotic kinds of lenses, while keeping the false positive rate low compared to algorithms. Discovery of this large sample of completely new candidates missed by some of these algorithms demonstrates that the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system is functioning well, the self-taught citizen scientists reaching parts of discovery space that the robots did not.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Further detailed qualitative and quantitative analysis of the properties of the entire S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> sample (new and previously identified candidates) and the mass modelling analyses for the new candidates will be presented in a subsequent S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> paper (Verma et\u00a0al., in preparation).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050603 id=\"92050603\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 Measurements of properties of the lens and the lensed images</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the subsequent sections, we compare various properties of the lens candidates. Here, we describe how we extract or measure these properties, namely, the lens redshift, the Einstein radii and the total flux of the lensed images or arcs.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the publicly available redshifts for the lens galaxy from the CFHTLS photometric catalogues (Coupon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). The total flux of the lensed image or arc is measured in the <em>g</em> band but the adopted method is different for different samples. For the simulated sample, we multiply the magnification of the second brightest image with the source magnitude. For the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> sample, the arcs are detected in the scaled difference image of <em>g</em> and <em>i</em> bands from which the lensing galaxy is subtracted (for details, see Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Here, we use the flux of the lensed images measured by SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> from the scaled difference image, that is, <em>g</em> \u2212 \u03b1<em>i</em> and convert it to the <em>g</em>-band flux using mean colours of the foreground and background population. For the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> and the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> sample, we integrate the flux in the image pixels identified by <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> or SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Einstein radius is also measured differently for different samples. For the galaxy-scale lenses in the simulated sample, we use the value of the input parameter of the lens model for the <em>R</em><sub>E</sub>. For group-scale lenses, since the lens model is multicomponent, we need to determine the <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> from the image positions. We use those pairs of lensed images that have the smallest and the largest angular separations. The <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> here is then half of the averaged values of these angular image separations. For the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> sample, we use the peak position of the lensed images measured by running SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> on the scaled difference image. We calculate the image separation from the lens centre as a rough estimate of the <em>R</em><sub>E</sub>. For the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> (SARCS) sample, we use the same definition as above except that the peak position is identified either by the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> or manually. For the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens sample, the same definition is used where the peak positions are identified either with <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> or SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050607 id=\"92050607\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-4>5.4 Recovery of known lens samples from the CFHTLS by S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now determine the fraction of the known sample of lenses that were recovered by S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>. Note that this sample corresponds to the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> samples combined, as defined in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>. In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we show that \u223c32\u2009per\u2009cent of the known lens candidates, and \u223c65\u2009per\u2009cent of the known lenses were found at Stage 1. We find that 56\u2009per\u2009cent of the known lens candidates and 87\u2009per\u2009cent of the known lenses from Stage 1 passed our Stage 2 selection criterion of <em>P</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.3 and <em>G</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a01.3. The left-hand and the middle panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> show the fraction of detections as a function of arc magnitude and the Einstein radius of the lens systems for the known confirmed lenses and lens candidates. As expected, we find that systems with brighter images and/or with larger <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> are detected more often in S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>.</p>                        <a id=\"92050609\" scrollto-destination=\"92050609\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" candidates and the simulated sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fraction of lens candidates recovered by S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> as a function of the arc magnitude (<em>g</em> band) and the Einstein radius for three lens samples, namely, the known lenses, the known lens candidates and the simulated sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=qQx~DFLp4yC7bhNWOIeLz19VUb0di3~ThXx0vCL~SRUnrnD5ZL6f5BP7fXbvD72vL82yh4Q03R8kJJvuhWL67e4XKVPIcC9dCsxlc9PaaceAIM1DtlAmPLZyw6IRmVDTkSCvrl0yPW48qVkOw1o6t6BpsDKtUSubMmA3UZRvrt7OTGQgQvjzx-c3HU1YpZ-TEM5~TsgjMjeIcCukz0P-VwkKepAPLNqeXau1YldE2~yyvtNJ~a~z~LdO1Q-pJYVRo-XPPI6IMEFYBqdj~OlG5jruD~iHFK~qob6UZZgdTv~GmcY395H9PJVwesKyQVCsj-opaysar361Na-yopzwdw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fraction of lens candidates recovered by Space\u00a0Warps as a function of the arc magnitude (g band) and the Einstein radius for three lens samples, namely, the known lenses, the known lens candidates and the simulated sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050609/stv1965fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050609\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=DPnH~zKM3w8XiqpqP5iw58e2aosXCEY0I451TJJQL~nNxSXYJF05vqh1sD~mI5ZA15yHh~hPLEpmNe5tapokgUb6QQQrdb5gcZB7FNbOx-QQU-yQQNuI6eV-l4Zq3IDDn5eB0gFPok4TiOxfcE51gaE53LoubAUzITQOdXNlheAMxA6ZTP6NAPZonZxX3tHQfESTkV4s3rjfj0qGXLLwvzXJKzS78UQwoE5QfOAjsq2E70fKt1K-bjk9MT109VxpyUEggQ63V7NeAnQsdAI7vL8qQYZTNI0-GDuAA7KtIJ6MAivLFwgXEvaA5HXqTdUouaPZXazRVLiPs7rq9EBp0A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050609&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fraction of lens candidates recovered by S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> as a function of the arc magnitude (<em>g</em> band) and the Einstein radius for three lens samples, namely, the known lenses, the known lens candidates and the simulated sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find that most of the confirmed lenses and candidates that are missed by S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> are systems from the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> sample, with fainter arcs and smaller <em>R</em><sub>E</sub>. The main reason why <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> found such candidates is because it involves subtracting the light from the lens galaxy, making it easier to detect the lensed images during both the automated object-finding, and the visual inspection and classification phases. This approach naturally improves the detection efficiency at smaller <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> and for fainter systems. The S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> volunteers were not shown any galaxy-subtracted images. Showing galaxy-subtracted images might be a better strategy to adopt for future lens searches at galaxy scales with S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>. However, we note that accurate modelling and subtraction of the galaxy light profile in different bands is challenging and better techniques are being actively developed to enhance detections of lenses at small image separations. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.3</a> below, we further explore and discuss why some of the confirmed lenses were missed by S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050611 id=\"92050611\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-5>5.5 Image separation distribution</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The distribution of image separations (i.e. 2 <em>R</em><sub>E</sub>) can be used to probe the average density profile of the lens population (Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). However, the lens sample found by the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> may have incompleteness as a function of the image separation. Thus, the lack of understanding of the selection function of the lens sample may affect the constraints on the density profile. A blind lens search done by visual inspection alone, for example, through S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> citizen scientists may find lenses missed by the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> search and thereby, improve completeness.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Indeed, we have found 59 new medium\u2013high grade lens candidates that were not known before. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, we show the image separation distribution using all the known and new lens candidates. The different data points are the known <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> sample (green), the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> identified (known and new) lens sample (blue) only and the combined CFHTLS sample of <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span>, <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> and the new S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens sample (magenta). It is interesting to note that both the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> +<span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> and S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> samples have very similar profiles and thus, the profile of the combined sample has not changed significantly. This implies that previous constraints on the image separation distribution are robust and the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> selected sample does not suffer from significant incompleteness for medium to large <em>R</em><sub>E</sub>. This is the regime that probes density profiles of galaxy groups to clusters.</p>                        <a id=\"92050614\" scrollto-destination=\"92050614\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=OoDwRSlUVVn4saUpjAHDRMbrIo5x9mO6ys4HLGyoUI4~6-aHedsuJxH5sN08lSGdX2VqU98sSU0UF6XSOBpCktRQ1w2qRP4yQ-ydo8ORt5Hj3P6NerS-cPt0C4V9xQB16TAtnOY3IDa5zJckGk~Ey1jS2rQzS~Gxx8lNZyUo093Rbzrho2IF4bEJ-8D3YvClRw0nL1hRWmi2obVhBCTH~kV8q2-Uzn-9P-UGK7I91xXT9N6ffVWOgSgFpu1NfCWc6F0LC6P2tegfibZnkb0EAQvyFg6ZtAWxtaCOq89gqvpENeP-07qYNkmV0FxatPrLiK5ykbZPvUQJ1XtFWhLjTQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Image separation distribution (ISD). Comparing theoretical predictions (solid curves) with the CFHTLS known lens samples (green) and the combined sample of known and Space\u00a0Warps lens candidates (magenta). The sample of new and the known lens candidates discovered from Space\u00a0Warps alone is shown in blue. The new updated profile of the ISD (magenta) is consistent with our previous measurements and strengthens our conclusion that the average density profiles of the lenses are similar to the Total profile.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050614/stv1965fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050614\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=M2j-~GcNeAbgA~K8ICNX-O0sKCRfKa8RWop4rYawa5cVl2306VV~9R~HBW2DR2DN0ymBWh6B44eAP5CCMvywygK-9cVmpuwDbCPKP~J3dKM7juQIgIdrKwU-BUgTTwcHIf8MesRVshKkBJHxmAfbrwnWLiBdHDSgkVOU8TW2FMOflq8vFZoPf2IKrJVVIqArfAP6v0FHR385II6RpOAOF80nwU-Es~vpnuaZsj6uvxiok-1cbW28bBRicl5JMmonYPfCqB0fofD5~rGhuLbQjdCeIlDjBAT~K058Goyg1AR5H6k8av0eYr9iKjvB8Cs5lrQ1kjUyHHXtW~1fSJAkwQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050614&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Image separation distribution (ISD). Comparing theoretical predictions (solid curves) with the CFHTLS known lens samples (green) and the combined sample of known and S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens candidates (magenta). The sample of new and the known lens candidates discovered from S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> alone is shown in blue. The new updated profile of the ISD (magenta) is consistent with our previous measurements and strengthens our conclusion that the average density profiles of the lenses are similar to the Total profile.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=OoDwRSlUVVn4saUpjAHDRMbrIo5x9mO6ys4HLGyoUI4~6-aHedsuJxH5sN08lSGdX2VqU98sSU0UF6XSOBpCktRQ1w2qRP4yQ-ydo8ORt5Hj3P6NerS-cPt0C4V9xQB16TAtnOY3IDa5zJckGk~Ey1jS2rQzS~Gxx8lNZyUo093Rbzrho2IF4bEJ-8D3YvClRw0nL1hRWmi2obVhBCTH~kV8q2-Uzn-9P-UGK7I91xXT9N6ffVWOgSgFpu1NfCWc6F0LC6P2tegfibZnkb0EAQvyFg6ZtAWxtaCOq89gqvpENeP-07qYNkmV0FxatPrLiK5ykbZPvUQJ1XtFWhLjTQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Image separation distribution (ISD). Comparing theoretical predictions (solid curves) with the CFHTLS known lens samples (green) and the combined sample of known and Space\u00a0Warps lens candidates (magenta). The sample of new and the known lens candidates discovered from Space\u00a0Warps alone is shown in blue. The new updated profile of the ISD (magenta) is consistent with our previous measurements and strengthens our conclusion that the average density profiles of the lenses are similar to the Total profile.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050614/stv1965fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050614\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=M2j-~GcNeAbgA~K8ICNX-O0sKCRfKa8RWop4rYawa5cVl2306VV~9R~HBW2DR2DN0ymBWh6B44eAP5CCMvywygK-9cVmpuwDbCPKP~J3dKM7juQIgIdrKwU-BUgTTwcHIf8MesRVshKkBJHxmAfbrwnWLiBdHDSgkVOU8TW2FMOflq8vFZoPf2IKrJVVIqArfAP6v0FHR385II6RpOAOF80nwU-Es~vpnuaZsj6uvxiok-1cbW28bBRicl5JMmonYPfCqB0fofD5~rGhuLbQjdCeIlDjBAT~K058Goyg1AR5H6k8av0eYr9iKjvB8Cs5lrQ1kjUyHHXtW~1fSJAkwQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050614&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Image separation distribution (ISD). Comparing theoretical predictions (solid curves) with the CFHTLS known lens samples (green) and the combined sample of known and S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens candidates (magenta). The sample of new and the known lens candidates discovered from S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> alone is shown in blue. The new updated profile of the ISD (magenta) is consistent with our previous measurements and strengthens our conclusion that the average density profiles of the lenses are similar to the Total profile.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the figure, we also show for comparison the theoretical predictions corresponding to three density profiles, namely, isothermal sphere (IS), NFW and a \u2018Total\u2019 profile which has NFW and Hernquist profiles combined with an adiabatically contracting model for the dark matter component (Gnedin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). These curves are taken from More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), which gives details of the calculation of these predictions. With the updated sample of lens candidates, we confirm our previous prediction that the mass density profiles of galaxy groups is indeed consistent with the \u2018Total\u2019 profile. At smaller image separations (\u22722\u00a0arcsec), the \u2018Total\u2019 profile converges to isothermal like case and assuming these predictions are reliable, we find that the lens samples have very low completeness. This is not too surprising compared to the 40\u2009per\u2009cent completeness expected for the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> sample (Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050616 id=\"92050616\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Finding gravitational lenses is a difficult and complex task. No single method is perfect, each method has some advantages over the other. It may be the case that a single method may never be the best method for optimizing completeness and purity. Visual inspection will likely be required for pruning candidates at some stage of lens candidate selection even in the future. Therefore, we would like to understand how best we should combine the strengths of robots and humans to optimize the lens-finding method.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we first compare the lens candidates found by S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> and the lens-finding robots and then attempt to understand why each method failed to detect lenses from the other sample.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050619 id=\"92050619\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1>6.1 Comparison of the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span>, S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> samples</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, we show the lens redshift and the arc flux measured in <em>g</em>-band AB magnitude as a function of the Einstein radius for the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> (green), the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> (red) and the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> sample (new candidates only in blue and known candidates as blue circles). We note that the errors on the redshift measurement should not be too different across the samples since they are measured by a single method. However, the error on the total flux of the lensed images is likely to be different across the samples and the types of systematics are also different. We have not attempted to quantify these errors in this work. With that caveat, we find that the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> candidates sample is broadly similar to the robotically found lens candidates in terms of the flux of the lensed images and the redshift of the lensing galaxies.</p>                        <a id=\"92050621\" scrollto-destination=\"92050621\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=QkB~dN1XiDx69BlytQ8q2Rlu-6y~95OymDtArY9Xf0EdkKDNeNgdShQYSw0Q4P0Gd4cf7OJbQBv0VH~4eaKZ23AdrIwWN6tcW6Wpd~Mb9FbBFx9p~BZqcgJjf5-Aoal5KyNdcZ7m8sm4cAcUPrSv2qXQbac1xp5WVGC4hmVLmrMXt9psAJHE7kn2whYk7exJRm66FTdDc9toGaT9GJXA6fyNRrQqp2uMPPHPg6yhgV9rUc4maRXcE2a5y5fupkIZ8eZ~4yKxQyECIRckSK7xoozuLc04zWNDXWZfPLKlvwDJTq~DxqW5ib9oKBQrGhIHtk4aH88xHMXM60qTl9iTGQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the lens redshift and the arc magnitude with the Einstein radius for all of the three lens samples, namely, the ringfinder (green dots), Space\u00a0Warps (known candidates\u2013blue circles; and new candidates only\u2013blue dots) and arcfinder (red dots). All samples have broadly similar properties.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050621/stv1965fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050621\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=EbCpaCLTd1q66phmJgJJseU292Z26mRWx09OsNT0pZCts~~iy3QnPeb4lkafRn8BlwjUP4FOXK0cu4b6nbepGTlatGw~jYtbSM51dNOvFUYoIKftJoHQ2kWGMD69hTgLIZQiYCxH1IH6fH1JoZN7H-YqwmC2mB2~kcI4zrCB7-EQM2S3iCDB0WYOJKAn5rNGq9IgYYakpgUaMr-teB8XYTdMyhKXKzIQIr87dDGZI6F5TlsOnK8qWA87DT1udc3dDUb5SRzyjI5R1EvO~JNQ2geSJcQwQ25N3B7DXxqVUKEIIjC3TDdOzD~OIGLkSt0RKa0l~ov0GXyNROMtkVJpgQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050621&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the lens redshift and the arc magnitude with the Einstein radius for all of the three lens samples, namely, the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> (green dots), S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> (known candidates\u2013blue circles; and new candidates only\u2013blue dots) and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> (red dots). All samples have broadly similar properties.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=QkB~dN1XiDx69BlytQ8q2Rlu-6y~95OymDtArY9Xf0EdkKDNeNgdShQYSw0Q4P0Gd4cf7OJbQBv0VH~4eaKZ23AdrIwWN6tcW6Wpd~Mb9FbBFx9p~BZqcgJjf5-Aoal5KyNdcZ7m8sm4cAcUPrSv2qXQbac1xp5WVGC4hmVLmrMXt9psAJHE7kn2whYk7exJRm66FTdDc9toGaT9GJXA6fyNRrQqp2uMPPHPg6yhgV9rUc4maRXcE2a5y5fupkIZ8eZ~4yKxQyECIRckSK7xoozuLc04zWNDXWZfPLKlvwDJTq~DxqW5ib9oKBQrGhIHtk4aH88xHMXM60qTl9iTGQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the lens redshift and the arc magnitude with the Einstein radius for all of the three lens samples, namely, the ringfinder (green dots), Space\u00a0Warps (known candidates\u2013blue circles; and new candidates only\u2013blue dots) and arcfinder (red dots). All samples have broadly similar properties.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050621/stv1965fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050621\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=EbCpaCLTd1q66phmJgJJseU292Z26mRWx09OsNT0pZCts~~iy3QnPeb4lkafRn8BlwjUP4FOXK0cu4b6nbepGTlatGw~jYtbSM51dNOvFUYoIKftJoHQ2kWGMD69hTgLIZQiYCxH1IH6fH1JoZN7H-YqwmC2mB2~kcI4zrCB7-EQM2S3iCDB0WYOJKAn5rNGq9IgYYakpgUaMr-teB8XYTdMyhKXKzIQIr87dDGZI6F5TlsOnK8qWA87DT1udc3dDUb5SRzyjI5R1EvO~JNQ2geSJcQwQ25N3B7DXxqVUKEIIjC3TDdOzD~OIGLkSt0RKa0l~ov0GXyNROMtkVJpgQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050621&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the lens redshift and the arc magnitude with the Einstein radius for all of the three lens samples, namely, the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> (green dots), S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> (known candidates\u2013blue circles; and new candidates only\u2013blue dots) and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> (red dots). All samples have broadly similar properties.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The properties considered here do not show any clear differences between the types of lenses being found by each method. Other properties such as the flux of the lensing galaxies and the surface brightness of the lensed images may be useful in showing some qualitative differences but this is beyond the scope of our current analysis. A more detailed and accurate analysis is deferred to future.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, we show the relative distribution of number of candidates from each sample as a function of the Einstein radius and arc magnitude. The light blue colour shows the overlap between the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> and the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> samples and the purple colour shows the overlap between the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> candidates and the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> samples. As noted earlier, the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> dominates the small <em>R</em><sub>E</sub>(&lt;2\u2009arcsec) detections although S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> does find a modest number of candidates in this range. At larger <em>R</em><sub>E</sub>, S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> sample begins to dominate and is comparable to the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> sample. As a function of the arc magnitudes, all three samples have detections at all magnitudes and median magnitudes for all samples is around <em>g</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a024.5. Relatively, the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> sample spans a narrower range compared to the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> sample. However, this can be verified only after understanding and accounting for the systematic uncertainties in our measurements.</p>                        <a id=\"92050624\" scrollto-destination=\"92050624\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img
