data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050624\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=Vn5v-jYVgOxcEUPMDKRwcy3gxJZkEwDnGPvGjDuIZvW-8LMp08K1aIPugLnHoMqDPqQrm6MVNU1QoogSkaWwmXatdi95~sb3mvIDSGnLPu-txUBsdNJxBvsargrnhxF41CuWYVGqJGWLZ-MbL1Lj2~eEYoHmDQ-X6GUaFM6lkJcbDho4yHKSEgqe15~tHJ~WyN~ZZwqU9M78Qlfm~kuvYVLYBdrurGQlWEIsv2UGTpX0x4FmcYGNOzSV6qxGR1Nl3~MUF3qHzr4114QDy0QGVtkh~VBVX98oSk88RvdZZp78as8kjAcq8W-73kAG5Hf-NwyrDsHoZMNWHE0Ecl4OtA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050624&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Candidate detections by the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span>, S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> and the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> as a function of the Einstein radius and <em>g</em>-band magnitude of the lensed images.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050625 id=\"92050625\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2>6.2 Why were the new S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> candidates missed by the robots?</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We test the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> on images centred on the new S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> candidates to trace and understand at what stage the algorithm failed to detect them.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">First, we reran <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> on the new S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> sample. At the beginning, a galaxy catalogue is generated based on magnitude, redshift and SED (spectral energy distribution) type (see Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) to select galaxies which are most likely to act as lenses. We find that about 40\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the new S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> candidates failed to meet this initial selection criteria, for example, SW1, SW14, SW20, SW23, SW27 and SW30. All of the lensing galaxies are bright enough to satisfy the magnitude criterion (<em>i</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a022). However, some of them have a bright companion galaxy, some of them do not look like E/S0 type galaxies and some are edge-on galaxies which could be the reason for these galaxies having failed the photometric redshift and SED type pre-selection.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In subsequent <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> steps, the flux from the galaxy is subtracted from the scaled difference image to enhance the visibility of the faint blue lensed features. An object finder is then run on this image to quantify the lensed image properties.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Another \u223c50\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> candidates could not be detected by the object finder because properties such as the image area, axis ratio, magnitude/colour and alignment with respect to the lensing galaxy were not satisfied. Some of the candidates missed at this stage are, for example, SW4, SW5, SW6, SW26, SW36, SW39 and SW46.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Next, we reran the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> on the same S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> sample of new candidates. The <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> is directly run on the images to look for elongated arc-like objects and does not require a list of targets to begin with. Objects are identified by placing thresholds on the noise level in the images. Thus, <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> detections are sensitive to changes in the noise levels.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Originally, the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> was run on a large image with an area of \u223c19\u2009350\u00a0\u00d7\u00a019\u2009350\u00a0pixels squared. For the rerun, we worked with much smaller images because this is faster. However, this alters the measured noise and hence affects the number and type of arc detections. We find that about 30\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the new candidates were detected without changing any of the thresholds in the code, suggesting that these could have been detected by <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> had its noise thresholds been set differently.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> code calculates second-order brightness moments around every pixel to decide if the distribution of flux is elongated in some direction in order to detect elongated arc-like objects. An elongation estimator is assigned to every pixel. All pixels with a value of the elongation estimator above a certain threshold are connected to form the arc feature. This is called the segmentation of the arc candidate. Subsequently, arc properties such as the area, mean flux, length and curvature are determined. We relaxed the threshold at the segmentation stage and also relaxed thresholds mainly on the area of the arc. These new settings led to the detection of about 75\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the new S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> candidates. We find that relaxing thresholds on other arc properties does not improve the detection rate significantly.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typically then, the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> candidates were missed from the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> sample either because (a) the arcs were fainter, (b) the flux of the arc and the galaxy were blended together (such that the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> incorrectly connected part of the galaxy to the arc), (c) the arcs were unusually short or thick, or (d) the lensed images are almost circular or point-like (<span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> was not designed to detect lensed quasars).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relaxing the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> thresholds obviously increases the number of candidate arc detections but this also increases the false positive rate. For example, the number of arc candidate detections increased by a factor of \u223c2 when we relaxed the thresholds in the rerun described above, while the number of false positives increased by a factor of \u223c5. While the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> sample purity could be increased by cross-correlating the arc candidate positions with a putative lens galaxy catalogue, these numbers illustrate the predicament facing automated lens-finding algorithms, and the continuing benefits of visual screening.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050635 id=\"92050635\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3>6.3 False negatives: known lenses missed by S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Like any lens-finding method, the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system could potentially be failing to detect certain kinds of lenses. We find that about 35\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the known sample of lenses are missed at Stage 1; about 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent losses were incurred during the Stage 2 refinement (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). Below, we focus on the known lens sample at Stage 1 to understand why some of them are being missed and possibly find a way to improve the detection rate which can be adopted in the future S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Many of the missed lenses are from the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> sample with small Einstein radii and faint lensed images (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). Among the confirmed lenses from <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span>, about 45\u00a0per\u00a0cent are missed. Out of the missed sample of 15 lenses, about half of them are visually difficult to detect. The other half appear to have faint blue smudges around galaxies which should have been easier to identify. Similarly, if we consider the <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> lens sample, \u223c20\u00a0per\u00a0cent are missed by S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>. This is a relatively small sample of \u223c5 systems and visual inspection of them suggests that, by and large, either the lensed features are faint or they have odd properties which makes them difficult to identify correctly. For further tests, we combine the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For a lens-finding method which uses the collective skill, experience and knowledge of a group of volunteers, it may be difficult to find a single factor with certainty which causes a lens candidate to be missed. We attempt to understand whether there is indeed a single dominant factor that is resulting in the loss of these lenses, or if the lenses are being missed due to a combination of multiple reasons. Below, we consider some of the factors that could affect the efficiency of finding lenses.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92050639 id=\"92050639\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3-1>6.3.1 Number of classifications</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">First, we check whether the number of classifications (Nclass) is significantly lower for the missed sample compared to the detected one. Most of the lenses in the known sample (including both those that were detected and those that were missed) received similar numbers of classifications to the other subjects. A few received Nclass&gt;20, possibly as a result of continuing to remain for a long time in the data base because there was uncertainty over whether or not to reject them. Overall, we do not find any difference in the number of classifications between the detected and the missed lenses.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92050641 id=\"92050641\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3-2>6.3.2 Lens positions within the image cut-outs</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The efficiency of a visual search could potentially vary in different sections of an image. Our eyes tend to focus usually at the centre of an image and lens candidates close to the borders could go undetected. Therefore, it is important to check whether S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> could be missing some of the known lenses because they happen to be close to the borders of the image cut-outs.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From the SWAP, the image cut-outs inspected by the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> volunteers receive a status of detected (if <em>P</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0<em>P</em><sub>accthresh</sub>), rejected (if <em>P</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>P</em><sub>rejthresh</sub>) and undecided (if <em>P</em><sub>rejthresh</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>P</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>P</em><sub>accthresh</sub>). In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, we compare the positions of lenses which are detected (red), undecided (green) and rejected (blue). The left-hand and the right-hand panels have the simulated lens sample and the known lens candidates sample, respectively. We note that the density of points do not represent the actual number of detections because, for cases with large sample size, randomly drawn subsamples are shown for the ease of visual comparison.</p>                        <a id=\"92050644\" scrollto-destination=\"92050644\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=P0dxIoddVjdZf5JWXcCf6wWVShkzsIhl17zKU69F6MjuoSmKXzxDkFhRuWPe0RY8e7D0uELE~f3CtzUxtRkjPhDDC0NCro6mKyGIUWlpzjNeKipS76bMQijYXMS87CBIqSeEOr4U9pL-I2IMEBobEojDLPUBNuT0PsrQd1DZhjvOA3fsu~k9NqM~Xk98h8abiPtXrsNLucAxXVBfFX3EqZ70r4hCjO5mI91yGI1Wg5gZbzlfVx3HkalPZmK0TRMUuDHFrlEb2lh4OOPcWAn4WH3nkTrwwFtLiSF81u9AmOspX~sD7jOYYK1yQpRTfhZiM2-6vv0HutcEiqhQQYHWIg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Completeness as a function of the positions of the lens systems. Simulated lenses (left) and real lens candidates (right) are shown. Irrespective of the status of the lenses, that is, detected, undecided or rejected, there is no strong dependency on the location of the lenses, both for the simulated and the real sample of candidates.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050644/stv1965fig10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050644\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=xg9vz8H9HyvuQW10EIklNeP2RzRS~IUONxBqQO4F9OF2x-vthk-UVnbIWwnH0DvT-Eoj8phIBIY9abWzCnCIZznsscs9inMP7nCkNxGuKTO9QhC1IeSrbE4Aa31Bh8ZL7VnT9vvSYJqisCYORagAFwYMdag2cTa-0yuwOshMZ5VkZeyNh-iGnz3hG6wM3rgIAZXResWILqZJGnH0k812FK4pcER-fRAljOypg9at7DjJErheA-nEl-9f~VJTvIxQFQA8eHUcOLP-zb63XtWXI6aLLTEkCqBSk8fqzZ9UdiaSWJRUUf5QuUViuaNFWa-20ZJwovtWRsZ1trv19bFfaQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050644&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Completeness as a function of the positions of the lens systems. Simulated lenses (left) and real lens candidates (right) are shown. Irrespective of the status of the lenses, that is, detected, undecided or rejected, there is no strong dependency on the location of the lenses, both for the simulated and the real sample of candidates.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=P0dxIoddVjdZf5JWXcCf6wWVShkzsIhl17zKU69F6MjuoSmKXzxDkFhRuWPe0RY8e7D0uELE~f3CtzUxtRkjPhDDC0NCro6mKyGIUWlpzjNeKipS76bMQijYXMS87CBIqSeEOr4U9pL-I2IMEBobEojDLPUBNuT0PsrQd1DZhjvOA3fsu~k9NqM~Xk98h8abiPtXrsNLucAxXVBfFX3EqZ70r4hCjO5mI91yGI1Wg5gZbzlfVx3HkalPZmK0TRMUuDHFrlEb2lh4OOPcWAn4WH3nkTrwwFtLiSF81u9AmOspX~sD7jOYYK1yQpRTfhZiM2-6vv0HutcEiqhQQYHWIg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Completeness as a function of the positions of the lens systems. Simulated lenses (left) and real lens candidates (right) are shown. Irrespective of the status of the lenses, that is, detected, undecided or rejected, there is no strong dependency on the location of the lenses, both for the simulated and the real sample of candidates.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050644/stv1965fig10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050644\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=xg9vz8H9HyvuQW10EIklNeP2RzRS~IUONxBqQO4F9OF2x-vthk-UVnbIWwnH0DvT-Eoj8phIBIY9abWzCnCIZznsscs9inMP7nCkNxGuKTO9QhC1IeSrbE4Aa31Bh8ZL7VnT9vvSYJqisCYORagAFwYMdag2cTa-0yuwOshMZ5VkZeyNh-iGnz3hG6wM3rgIAZXResWILqZJGnH0k812FK4pcER-fRAljOypg9at7DjJErheA-nEl-9f~VJTvIxQFQA8eHUcOLP-zb63XtWXI6aLLTEkCqBSk8fqzZ9UdiaSWJRUUf5QuUViuaNFWa-20ZJwovtWRsZ1trv19bFfaQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050644&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Completeness as a function of the positions of the lens systems. Simulated lenses (left) and real lens candidates (right) are shown. Irrespective of the status of the lenses, that is, detected, undecided or rejected, there is no strong dependency on the location of the lenses, both for the simulated and the real sample of candidates.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We do not find any strong correlation in the detection rate of lenses as a function of their positions in the image, for either the simulated or the known lens sample. Thus, the completeness of the lens sample is most likely not significantly affected by lenses located close to the image borders.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92050646 id=\"92050646\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3-3>6.3.3 Classification power</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Each S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> image classification is based on the markers placed by around 10 volunteers (on average, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper I</a>). This number could be small enough to introduce some scatter in the system performance, arising from the variations between the small groups of volunteers inspecting each subject. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper I</a> we investigated the system performance in terms of the \u2018Skill\u2019 of each agent; in Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a> we define a complementary property, the \u2018Power\u2019 of a classification to make a large difference in the probability <em>P</em> of an image containing a lens. Here, we investigate whether the distribution of classification power is systematically different between the detected and missed lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We check how the posterior probability <em>P</em> (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper I</a> for the mathematical definition) of an image or a subject to contain a lens changes as the image receives more classifications from multiple volunteers. A graphical representation of changing probabilities for increasing classifications is called a trajectory plot. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, we show the trajectory plots of a few examples of detected lenses (top row of panels) and missed lenses (bottom row of panels) from Stage 1 of S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>. Every subject is assigned a prior probability <em>P</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup> (grey dashed line) and starts at the middle of the trajectory plot. The number of classifications (Nclass) for a subject increases from top to bottom (subjects move down the trajectory plots as they are classified). The <em>P</em> value of a subject is updated with every classification from the volunteer. If a volunteer identifies a lens candidate, the trajectory moves to the right otherwise moves to the left. A subject is accepted if it crosses the blue-dashed line marking the <em>P</em><sub>accthresh</sub> (set to 0.95 for Stage 1) on the right. It is rejected if it crosses the red-dashed line marking the <em>P</em><sub>rejthresh</sub> (set to 10<sup>\u22127</sup> for Stage 1) on the left.</p>                        <a id=\"92050649\" scrollto-destination=\"92050649\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=UTody8I5QKakjqXyjr1mz~a-lCpSgOx0DhJQ~8N59YgpTniuP1h84JFrZNorMQJtJoeavpiJ2e7uhiVBVY8rGvMNF65rK92mtKZMuCIPcaDFwpeKUQBNzxraH0QzKg4uiBLpWDGoxm3xVSeOR~ahLuu5Vcpa3EhZ1goxpCMctNyk-h8ffgtmJRbPaWkpy21g3SOy04f38qKuxZro~rvP2cNLlA0WD8UOr~7b6qidXIfvNdeR~YAHCSoE2M7yOmFwhs1rvEvC0YeDNXSrGCCGAjGwGRLwRSLGTxPSpuDfvkQnZ2YCUNaV-8O~DSgD-JQbLE64aBDL2ShpcF311WmpcQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: examples of Stage 1 trajectories of some known lenses. Upper panels show detected lenses, lower panels show missed lenses (false negatives). The green trajectories for the detected sample are counterparts of the light and dark green trajectories of the missed sample except that the kicks are positive for the detected sample. The red trajectories of the detected sample demonstrate that sufficient number of positive large kicks can lead to the detection of the lenses. Within the missed sample, the light and dark green correspond to visually easier and more difficult to identify systems, respectively. Right: histogram of classification power received by known lenses. Among the sample of missed lenses, most classifications are from the low-power volunteers identifying these images incorrectly (i.e. \u2212\u0394 log(P)) which overshadows the small number of correct identifications (i.e. \u0394 log(P)) coming from both the less- and the high-power volunteers combined. For the detected lens sample, most classifications are correct identifications coming from both low- and high-power volunteers.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050649/stv1965fig11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050649\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=EyaCiKjtrbjZso5TgKX2uiAIUEUqscZQJOScnLyJJ-t~y8JKd2S1ZZjc1BVNqVrn2siMyaE7fWH0pGddlCrfiMxfCabQ4KuRsBgwW5PUIrNUYXIERqO5BDuw3qXtz5qXEEAtPh0a1JilBClmfZa0jmosa-ZEeao8GgoFKhRTx1yYK7VCS8Q1tKSfoxbooWyiPCE3Hoj-wJnM0l9n4QyJ9eQl1x2fZjA67i-ur3MyrTEtp~aF9B2VhiCs8qS19icWjNkJ4zFVTyPLmOaRA5fZPg-e0RWcNRHodS82P7HnSu6DUVIjaLtKuse3ToAhsAHk18yWrRYM23VcZpTzDG4lJQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050649&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Left: examples of Stage 1 trajectories of some known lenses. Upper panels show detected lenses, lower panels show missed lenses (false negatives). The green trajectories for the detected sample are counterparts of the light and dark green trajectories of the missed sample except that the kicks are positive for the detected sample. The red trajectories of the detected sample demonstrate that sufficient number of positive large kicks can lead to the detection of the lenses. Within the missed sample, the light and dark green correspond to visually easier and more difficult to identify systems, respectively. Right: histogram of classification power received by known lenses. Among the sample of missed lenses, most classifications are from the low-power volunteers identifying these images incorrectly (i.e. \u2212\u0394 log(<em>P</em>)) which overshadows the small number of correct identifications (i.e. \u0394 log(<em>P</em>)) coming from both the less- and the high-power volunteers combined. For the detected lens sample, most classifications are correct identifications coming from both low- and high-power volunteers.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=UTody8I5QKakjqXyjr1mz~a-lCpSgOx0DhJQ~8N59YgpTniuP1h84JFrZNorMQJtJoeavpiJ2e7uhiVBVY8rGvMNF65rK92mtKZMuCIPcaDFwpeKUQBNzxraH0QzKg4uiBLpWDGoxm3xVSeOR~ahLuu5Vcpa3EhZ1goxpCMctNyk-h8ffgtmJRbPaWkpy21g3SOy04f38qKuxZro~rvP2cNLlA0WD8UOr~7b6qidXIfvNdeR~YAHCSoE2M7yOmFwhs1rvEvC0YeDNXSrGCCGAjGwGRLwRSLGTxPSpuDfvkQnZ2YCUNaV-8O~DSgD-JQbLE64aBDL2ShpcF311WmpcQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: examples of Stage 1 trajectories of some known lenses. Upper panels show detected lenses, lower panels show missed lenses (false negatives). The green trajectories for the detected sample are counterparts of the light and dark green trajectories of the missed sample except that the kicks are positive for the detected sample. The red trajectories of the detected sample demonstrate that sufficient number of positive large kicks can lead to the detection of the lenses. Within the missed sample, the light and dark green correspond to visually easier and more difficult to identify systems, respectively. Right: histogram of classification power received by known lenses. Among the sample of missed lenses, most classifications are from the low-power volunteers identifying these images incorrectly (i.e. \u2212\u0394 log(P)) which overshadows the small number of correct identifications (i.e. \u0394 log(P)) coming from both the less- and the high-power volunteers combined. For the detected lens sample, most classifications are correct identifications coming from both low- and high-power volunteers.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050649/stv1965fig11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050649\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=EyaCiKjtrbjZso5TgKX2uiAIUEUqscZQJOScnLyJJ-t~y8JKd2S1ZZjc1BVNqVrn2siMyaE7fWH0pGddlCrfiMxfCabQ4KuRsBgwW5PUIrNUYXIERqO5BDuw3qXtz5qXEEAtPh0a1JilBClmfZa0jmosa-ZEeao8GgoFKhRTx1yYK7VCS8Q1tKSfoxbooWyiPCE3Hoj-wJnM0l9n4QyJ9eQl1x2fZjA67i-ur3MyrTEtp~aF9B2VhiCs8qS19icWjNkJ4zFVTyPLmOaRA5fZPg-e0RWcNRHodS82P7HnSu6DUVIjaLtKuse3ToAhsAHk18yWrRYM23VcZpTzDG4lJQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050649&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965fig11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Left: examples of Stage 1 trajectories of some known lenses. Upper panels show detected lenses, lower panels show missed lenses (false negatives). The green trajectories for the detected sample are counterparts of the light and dark green trajectories of the missed sample except that the kicks are positive for the detected sample. The red trajectories of the detected sample demonstrate that sufficient number of positive large kicks can lead to the detection of the lenses. Within the missed sample, the light and dark green correspond to visually easier and more difficult to identify systems, respectively. Right: histogram of classification power received by known lenses. Among the sample of missed lenses, most classifications are from the low-power volunteers identifying these images incorrectly (i.e. \u2212\u0394 log(<em>P</em>)) which overshadows the small number of correct identifications (i.e. \u0394 log(<em>P</em>)) coming from both the less- and the high-power volunteers combined. For the detected lens sample, most classifications are correct identifications coming from both low- and high-power volunteers.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The amount by which the posterior probability <em>P</em> value of a subject will change depends on how well the volunteers are performing on the training sample and its current probability. Thus, for a given current probability, some volunteers will change the <em>P</em> by a large factor compared to others. This is evident in the trajectory plots, which show both large and small distances between consecutive points which we refer to as kicks. Comparison of the kick sizes between the detected and the missed lenses suggests that <em>the missed lenses do not have as many volunteers giving large kicks</em>. We also note that most of the large kicks seen in the trajectories of the missed lenses seem to be moving the subjects to the right. In other words, certain \u2018high-power\u2019 volunteers are mostly classifying them as subjects with lens candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The bottom panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, show the trajectories of missed lenses for the cases which are visually easier (light green) and more difficult (dark green) to identify. In spite of some mild qualitative differences, both set of trajectories have very similar behaviour. The trajectories in panel (e) are typical of this sample in terms of Nclass and the dominance of small negative kicks. Panel (f) represents a small fraction of this sample where the kicks are only small and negative. The panel (g) shows how some lenses receive a bunch of large positive kicks which are led to rejection by still mostly small negative kicks. Finally, panel (h) shows those cases of lenses which received almost sufficient number of large positive kicks to be detected but ended up being rejected.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The detected lenses shown with green trajectories, in the upper panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, can be thought of as counterparts of the trajectories of the missed lenses in the corresponding bottom panels except that their classification power is different. Most detected lenses are similar to the case in panel (a) that are detected within a few classifications coming from large positive kicks. Panel (b) represents a few odd cases which are dominated mainly by small positive kicks. Panel (c) shows a lens getting more classifications, but not reaching the detection or rejection thresholds because of the tug between positive and negative kicks mostly from experienced volunteers. Panel (d) represents two extreme cases when the images are on the verge of being rejected but are saved thanks to a series of large positive kicks. The red trajectories are some more examples of randomly selected cases which demonstrate how having sufficient number of large positive kicks allows lenses to be detected in spite of several small negative kicks.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For a quantitative comparison of the large and small kicks for the entire samples of detected and missed known lenses, we show a plot of histogram on the right of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>. Qualitatively, there are four types of volunteers making classifications: those causing large, positive kicks (correct classifications by high-power volunteers), those causing small, positive kicks (correct classifications by low-power volunteers), those causing small, negative kicks (incorrect classifications by low-power volunteers) and those causing large, negative kicks (incorrect classifications by high-power volunteers). The four histograms in the figure correspond to these four types of volunteers for each sample (that is, detected or missed). In this plot, the kick size is defined as small if \u0394log\u2009<em>P</em>(\u00a0=\u00a0log\u2009<em>P</em><sub>current</sub> \u2212 log\u2009<em>P</em><sub>previous</sub>)\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u0394log\u2009<em>P</em><sub>cut</sub> (chosen as 1.2) and is large if greater than \u0394log\u2009<em>P</em><sub>cut</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Some of the key inferences are as follows. (i) The ratio of positive kicks to negative kicks for the detected sample is higher than in the missed sample, suggesting that the fraction of volunteers making positive kicks is higher for the detected sample. (ii) The number of classifications received by the missed sample is dominated by small negative kicks. In contrast, for the detected sample there are comparable contributions from all three types \u2013 small positive kicks, large positive kicks and small negative kicks. (iii) The number of classifications providing large negative kicks is lower for both the detected and the missed samples. This is consistent with our expectation that high-power volunteers should not be making incorrect classifications. We conclude that one of the major factors in the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system missing the known lenses is a lack of high-power classifications.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As a demonstration, we reran SWAP for Stage 1 using only classifications that produced large kicks, with |\u0394log\u2009<em>P</em>|\u00a0&gt;\u00a01.2. This obviously meant reducing the total number of classifications per subject by a large fraction. As a result, we also needed to change the <em>P</em><sub>accthresh</sub>. Choosing this to be 0.1, we found that about a third of the lenses that had previously been missed were now detected, while all the previously detected lenses were again detected. The remaining missed lenses simply do not have enough classifications from volunteers producing large positive kicks. This experiment shows that it may be possible to increase the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> completeness by preferentially showing certain rejected systems \u2013 those that had never received a high-power classification \u2013 to volunteers capable of making such classifications.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Changing the rejection and acceptance thresholds will likely decrease the purity along with improved completeness. This will need to be further quantified before detailed recommendations can be made. However, dynamically assigning certain subjects to volunteers according to various measures of their skill seems like a fruitful line of investigation when seeking to improve the system performance in future.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050657 id=\"92050657\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery of gravitational lens candidates from the first S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens search. In this search, volunteers were shown <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> colour images of random regions of the sky taken by the CFHT Legacy Survey. The aim of this blind lens search was to find lenses that had been missed by previous searches done on the CFHTLS with lens-finding algorithms.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The search was carried out in two stages. In Stage 1, volunteers inspected \u223c430\u00a0000 images, and selected a smaller sample of \u223c3000 images as having interesting lens candidates. In Stage 2, after a careful second inspection of the candidates from Stage 1, a purer sample of \u223c500 candidates was obtained. In a final step, these images were inspected by three of us (AM, AV and PJM) to produce a sample of candidates with grades ranging from possibly a lens (1) to almost certainly a lens (3). In this paper, we presented this new S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> sample and compared it with the previously known samples from two robotic searches from the CFHTLS, namely, <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our conclusions are as follows. </p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> works well as a discovery engine for gravitational lenses through citizen science. While a targeted visual search may be more efficient, we show that the blind search works reasonably well too.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use a sample of simulated lenses, duds and impostors tailored to the CFHTLS data to train the volunteers and calibrate their performance. The volunteers not only perform well on the training sample (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper I</a>) but also find lenses that are fainter, more compact or redder than covered by the training sample demonstrating their adaptability in this task.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a sample of 29 new gravitational lens candidates, and an additional 30 medium grade systems. These 59 candidates received averaged grade <em>G</em>\u22651.3 from three experts following the scale where 1 means possibly, 2 means probably, and 3 means almost certainly, a lens. In addition, among the <em>G</em>\u22651.3 sample, we rediscovered 82 lens candidates from various samples published in the literature.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Compared to the sample of <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span> robotically detected lens candidates, the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> sample finds lens systems with statistically similar properties, including the range of lens redshifts, lensed image total magnitudes, and Einstein radii. However, having only displayed images without the lens galaxy light subtracted, the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> sample does not contain many of the <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span>-identified-lensed images with subarcsecond <em>R</em><sub>E</sub>, just because the flux of the typically faint lensed images is obscured by the flux from bright lensing galaxies.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Qualitatively, S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> seems to have found lens systems with different types of lensing galaxies, for example, elliptical, spiral (face on and edge on) and small red galaxies unlike those found from robotic searches. Similarly, the lensed images too have diverse properties such as different colours, morphologies and sizes which are again typically missed by any given algorithm.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on the known sample of lenses and lens candidates, we find that we lose a small fraction of them during Stage 2 refinement. It is more important to improve the lens detection sensitivity at the initial Stage 1 classification step. About 35\u2009per\u2009cent of the known lenses (20 in total) were missed at Stage 1. Two-thirds of these missed lenses were found to be galaxy-scale <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> systems, with faint arcs blended with the bright lens galaxies.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is possible to improve the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> completeness by changing the strategy of when and who is shown an image: only using high-power classifications recovers 40\u2009per\u2009cent of the missed lenses.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">The discovery of many new lens candidates through the first S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> lens search has demonstrated that the citizen scientists have successfully taught themselves to identify lenses within a short span of time. They have found lens candidates that the algorithms failed to discover. Upcoming and planned wide-field imaging surveys such as the DES, HSC, <em>Euclid</em> and LSST will produce formidable amounts of data. Blind lens searches as described here will be impractical with these very large surveys. However, it should be possible to conduct a blind search on a subarea of a large survey in order to assess the performance of either the algorithms or the volunteers, the results of which can be extrapolated to the entire survey. As demonstrated in this paper, any one approach for finding lenses from the entire survey data may not be sufficiently complete and pure. Thus, combining robotic methods for pre-selection with the citizen science approach for visual screening might be a good strategy for finding lenses in these large imaging surveys.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank all 36\u00a0982 members of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> community for their contributions to the project so far. A complete list of registered collaborators is provided at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://spacewarps.org/#/projects/CFHTLS\" target=\"_blank\">http://spacewarps.org/#/projects/CFHTLS</a>. We also thank the anonymous referee for useful comments on the paper.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">PJM was given support by the Royal Society, in the form of a research fellowship, and by the US Department of Energy under contract no. DE-AC02-76SF00515. AV acknowledges support from the Leverhulme Trust in the form of a research fellowship. The work of AM and SM was supported by World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI Initiative), MEXT, Japan. AM acknowledges the support of the Japan Society for Promotion of Science (JSPS) fellowship. The work of AM was also supported in part by National Science Foundation Grant no. PHYS-1066293 and the hospitality of the Aspen Center for Physics.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> project is open source. The web app was developed at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/Zooniverse/Lens-Zoo\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/Zooniverse/Lens-Zoo</a>, and was supported by a grant from the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, while the SWAP analysis software was developed at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/drphilmarshall/SpaceWarps\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/drphilmarshall/SpaceWarps</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The CFHTLS data used in this work are based on observations obtained with MegaPrime/MegaCam, a joint project of CFHT and CEA/IRFU, at the CFHT which is operated by the National Research Council (NRC) of Canada, the Institut National des Science de l'Univers of the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) of France, and the University of Hawaii. This work is based in part on data products produced at <span class=\"small-caps\">terapix</span> available at the Canadian Astronomy Data Centre as part of the CFHTLS, a collaborative project of NRC and CNRS.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://admin.masterlens.org/index.php\" target=\"_blank\">http://admin.masterlens.org/index.php</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.cfht.hawaii.edu/Science/CFHTLS/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.cfht.hawaii.edu/Science/CFHTLS/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">These numbers are estimated from <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://terapix.iap.fr/cplt/T0007/doc/T0007-doc.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">http://terapix.iap.fr/cplt/T0007/doc/T0007-doc.pdf</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.ita.uni-heidelberg.de/\u223cmaturi/Public/arcs\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.ita.uni-heidelberg.de/\u223cmaturi/Public/arcs</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">5</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://talk.spacewarps.org/\" target=\"_blank\">http://talk.spacewarps.org/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn6\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn6\" class=\"end-note-link\">6</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The open source colour image composition code used in this work is available from <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://github.com/drphilmarshall/HumVI\" target=\"_blank\">http://github.com/drphilmarshall/HumVI</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn7\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn7\" class=\"end-note-link\">7</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Due to inaccuracies and uncertainties in measurements of the centres of some of the lens candidates, some simulated lensed images were superposed on the galaxies of known lens candidates. This issue was overcome by presenting the same CFHTLS images with and without the simulated lenses to the volunteers.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn8\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn8\" class=\"end-note-link\">8</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We anchor our <em>L</em><sub>*</sub> evolution at low redshifts using the determination of <em>L</em><sub>*</sub> in the <em>r</em> band by Blanton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). To maintain consistency in magnitude systems, we have converted the CFHT MegaCAM magnitudes to SDSS magnitudes and <em>k</em>-corrected them to <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.1.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn9\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn9\" class=\"end-note-link\">9</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">In a flux-limited sample from a survey, sources fainter than the flux limit end up in the sample owing to the magnification by lensing which is known as the magnification bias. This affects the source luminosity function and needs to be accounted for when comparing the true and observed luminosity functions.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn10\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn10\" class=\"end-note-link\">10</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">This was due to an oversight. We intended to use either an exponential or de Vaucouleurs\u2019 profile that will be adopted for future implementations of SIMCT.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn11\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn11\" class=\"end-note-link\">11</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The lens mass distribution determines size and shape of the caustics. Any source located within the caustics will form multiple lensed images which is the criteria for strong lensing. To further understand caustics, see e.g. Schneider, Ehlers &amp; Falco (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn12\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn12\" class=\"end-note-link\">12</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">This estimate is based on the number of #simfail tags from TALK, the discussion forum.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn13\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn13\" class=\"end-note-link\">13</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">If grades from the inspectors were found to be discrepant by 2 or more, these were discussed and re-graded to resolve the discrepancy.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050682 id=\"92050682\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div H.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n             <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Halkola</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n          </span>\r\n          <div class=\"year\">2010</div>\r\n          <div class=\"source \">A&amp;A</div>\r\n          <div class=\"volume\">524</div>\r\n          <div class=\"fpage\">A94</div>\r\n        </p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201015481\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1051%2F0004-6361%2F201015481\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1051%2F0004-6361%2F201015481\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib55\" data-legacy-id=\"bib55\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib55\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib55\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib55\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n          <span class=\"person-group\">\r\n            <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Sygnet</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">J. F.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n             <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Tu</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">H.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n             <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Fort</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">B.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n             <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Gavazzi</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">R.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n          </span>\r\n          <div class=\"year\">2010</div>\r\n          <div class=\"source \">A&amp;A</div>\r\n          <div class=\"volume\">517</div>\r\n          <div class=\"fpage\">A25</div>\r\n        </p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/200913977\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1051%2F0004-6361%2F200913977\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1051%2F0004-6361%2F200913977\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib56\" data-legacy-id=\"bib56\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib56\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib56\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib56\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n          <span class=\"person-group\">\r\n            <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Thanjavur</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">K.      </p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n          <span class=\"person-group\">\r\n            <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Zheng</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">W.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            et al.\u00a0\r\n          </span>\r\n          <div class=\"year\">2012</div>\r\n          <div class=\"source \">Nature</div>\r\n          <div class=\"volume\">489</div>\r\n          <div class=\"fpage\">406</div>\r\n        </p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature11446\" href=\"http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22996554\" class=\"link link-pub-id openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">PubMed</a></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib59\" data-legacy-id=\"bib59\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib59\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib59\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib59\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n          <span class=\"person-group\">\r\n            <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Zitrin</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n             <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Broadhurst</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n          </span>\r\n          <div class=\"year\">2009</div>\r\n          <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>\r\n          <div class=\"volume\">703</div>\r\n          <div class=\"fpage\">L132</div>\r\n        </p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/703/2/L132\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F703%2F2%2FL132\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F703%2F2%2FL132\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib60\" data-legacy-id=\"bib60\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib60\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib60\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib60\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n          <span class=\"person-group\">\r\n            <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Zitrin</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n             <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Broadhurst</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n             <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Barkana</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">R.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n             <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Rephaeli</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">Y.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n             <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Ben\u00edtez</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">N.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n          </span>\r\n          <div class=\"year\">2011</div>\r\n          <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>\r\n          <div class=\"volume\">410</div>\r\n          <div class=\"fpage\">1939</div>\r\n        </p><!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\">\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050684 id=\"92050684\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX A: LENS DETECTION POWER</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper I</a>, we defined the \u2018Skill\u2019 of an agent as being given by the expectation value of the information gain per classification. This quantity is a non-linear function of both the <em>P</em><sub>L</sub>, the probability of correctly identifying a lens as a lens and <em>P</em><sub>D</sub>, the probability of correctly identifying a dud as a dud. This means that one can get the same value of Skill for different combinations of <em>P</em><sub>L</sub> and <em>P</em><sub>D</sub> (see the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa1\" data-open=\"figa1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>). The skill reflects the all-round ability of a classifier to contribute information.</p>                        <a id=\"92050686\" scrollto-destination=\"92050686\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=A959UykI0sIJ6rNSddN6UA-gDgLXeNcawLw~afBmzQLmtBsqXjNhj~5sua2eRdeBa8bcfWDilN9AAR3xGl7451Em~gjL3f0Vx4yqjkZU13UuODfXv3k4tS1DtMzGfPA2pKpnaD00I8ltFf9X53-uzdef78AoYl23uWTOc7nyvs~m3w4d7Llm3cQhHTHjS2RpYsKztob1dmJzixPMTORbsY53BpvLmS7KlICNehOdNksEIKvQcBB9~lIfaE-BOC6AcJsGwwRSoM5BZKlfAxV8kQVvNDuhWRJPfy5vYRuyINUVUr7HYH3eqQ4y79qyWxnNz70p5lx3YSC~37qecEsQOQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Skill of the volunteers and \u0394log\u2009P given a lens or not a lens in an image as a function of PL and PD. These quantities indicate the ability of the volunteers but do not have a simple linear relation with PL and PD.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965figa1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050686/stv1965figa1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965figa1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050686\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=ZLJk~~NWv5zLeED-Ze1zsZjNnKdKEqrdtAhtFWk63VddI2FTEINkwuwvTZkM8otLsFKgXMHv7LhdgHzr0uhbbyn6PH5xvm6Abt28o~4umVxbTMdkQC80nHBEojaE0pWAz~k8skuSiXt8X9QVez-YNalr7Dic7bGFTaqzJJfttHcKUWyyS-ymEMWEHQ4bVSpHSDYvsvqvj3HclZTgogHTcvV4BQj9DaeW1i5x7rtfilb7CY6NoQbF3R~ek8Y9hYycYbFaA2-KcS3So~JIUZFkL-7imz3dlATI4Ft8aIGO7FHoO2X6WYe5gO8ZyZ5-GtwkMJTkWmzieMGNGV~2RbNXoA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050686&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965figa1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Skill of the volunteers and \u0394log\u2009<em>P</em> given a lens or not a lens in an image as a function of <em>P</em><sub>L</sub> and <em>P</em><sub>D</sub>. These quantities indicate the ability of the volunteers but do not have a simple linear relation with <em>P</em><sub>L</sub> and <em>P</em><sub>D</sub>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/m_stv1965figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&amp;Signature=A959UykI0sIJ6rNSddN6UA-gDgLXeNcawLw~afBmzQLmtBsqXjNhj~5sua2eRdeBa8bcfWDilN9AAR3xGl7451Em~gjL3f0Vx4yqjkZU13UuODfXv3k4tS1DtMzGfPA2pKpnaD00I8ltFf9X53-uzdef78AoYl23uWTOc7nyvs~m3w4d7Llm3cQhHTHjS2RpYsKztob1dmJzixPMTORbsY53BpvLmS7KlICNehOdNksEIKvQcBB9~lIfaE-BOC6AcJsGwwRSoM5BZKlfAxV8kQVvNDuhWRJPfy5vYRuyINUVUr7HYH3eqQ4y79qyWxnNz70p5lx3YSC~37qecEsQOQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Skill of the volunteers and \u0394log\u2009P given a lens or not a lens in an image as a function of PL and PD. These quantities indicate the ability of the volunteers but do not have a simple linear relation with PL and PD.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965figa1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050686/stv1965figa1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965figa1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050686\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv1965/2/stv1965figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611467264&Signature=ZLJk~~NWv5zLeED-Ze1zsZjNnKdKEqrdtAhtFWk63VddI2FTEINkwuwvTZkM8otLsFKgXMHv7LhdgHzr0uhbbyn6PH5xvm6Abt28o~4umVxbTMdkQC80nHBEojaE0pWAz~k8skuSiXt8X9QVez-YNalr7Dic7bGFTaqzJJfttHcKUWyyS-ymEMWEHQ4bVSpHSDYvsvqvj3HclZTgogHTcvV4BQj9DaeW1i5x7rtfilb7CY6NoQbF3R~ek8Y9hYycYbFaA2-KcS3So~JIUZFkL-7imz3dlATI4Ft8aIGO7FHoO2X6WYe5gO8ZyZ5-GtwkMJTkWmzieMGNGV~2RbNXoA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050686&ar=1103045&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv1965figa1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Skill of the volunteers and \u0394log\u2009<em>P</em> given a lens or not a lens in an image as a function of <em>P</em><sub>L</sub> and <em>P</em><sub>D</sub>. These quantities indicate the ability of the volunteers but do not have a simple linear relation with <em>P</em><sub>L</sub> and <em>P</em><sub>D</sub>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper I</a>, the posterior probability <em>P</em> of a subject is determined by the <em>P</em><sub>L</sub> and <em>P</em><sub>D</sub> of all the volunteers who clicked on the subject, via Bayes\u2019 Theorem. Each agent will apply a \u2018kick\u2019 of a different size to the subject probability, \u0394log\u2009<em>P</em>, which can be either positive (if the classifier thinks the subject contains a lens) or negative (if the classifier thinks the subject does not contain a lens). For instance, given a subject containing a lens, a volunteer with high <em>P</em><sub>L</sub> implies a large positive kick irrespective of the value of <em>P</em><sub>D</sub>, as shown in the middle panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa1\" data-open=\"figa1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>. However, large positive kicks are still possible for a volunteer located in the upper triangle with different combinations of (<em>P</em><sub>L</sub>, <em>P</em><sub>D</sub>) suggesting that the kick is not a simple function of (<em>P</em><sub>L</sub>, <em>P</em><sub>D</sub>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The kicks appear as steps on the subject's trajectory plot. This kick magnitude gives a useful measure of an agent's \u2018Power\u2019 to move images closer to detection. Note that a volunteer who is very good at rejecting duds, but not so good at identifying lenses, may have a high Skill but a low Power (since they may fail to detect many of the interesting lenses): Power provides a more precise quantification of a classifier's ability to detect lenses (compared to rejecting non-lenses).</p>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n<div class=\"copyright copyright-statement\">\u00a9 2015 The Authors Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of the Royal Astronomical Society</div><!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n        <span id=\"UserHasAccess\" data-userHasAccess=\"True\"></span>\r\n\r\n    </div><!-- /.widget-items -->\r\n</div><!-- "Complete", "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": " class=\"chapter-para\">We show images of our new sample in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5a\" data-open=\"fig5a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. The panels are arranged first in the descending order of their grades, and within each grade, in ascending order of RA. As the first lens search was a blind search with no pre-selection of candidates from any algorithm, we find various types of lenses, as expected from such a search. The final sample consists of both galaxy- and group-scale lens candidates. There are detections of elongated arcs and some interesting point-like quasar lensed images. Most of them are brighter in the bluer <em>g</em> band, but some candidates brighter in the redder <em>i</em> band are also found. Since the robotic lens searches focused on the blue lensed features, they are likely to miss such interesting lens candidates. We did not find any examples of exotic lens candidates from the visually inspected <em>P</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.3 sample. There may be some more interesting candidates that were missed either at Stage 1 or Stage 2 but have been identified by volunteers in Talk. This resource is yet to be mined and is left for future work."}, "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 3": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 4": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Table correctly loaded": "", "Detection table": "", "Discovery": "Space Warps: check", "Lens Kind": "Mix GAL-GAL, GAL-QSO", "Message on table quality": "Check if Space Warps should be an acronym used in MLD"}, "Table map to MasterLens database": {"System Name": "('Unnamed: 1_level_0', 'Name')", "Alternate Name(s)": "('Unnamed: 0_level_0', 'SW ID')", "RA [\u00b0]": "('RA', '(deg)')", "Dec [\u00b0]": "('Dec', '(deg)')", "z_Lens": "('Unnamed: 4_level_0', 'zphot')@photometric@", "Einstein_R [\"]": "('RE', '(arcsec)')@1/2 image separation@"}}}}}}, "Tables status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "SPACE WARPS- II. New gravitational lens candidates from the CFHTLS discovered through citizen science", "authors": ["More, Anupreeta", "Verma, Aprajita", "Marshall, Philip J.", "More, Surhud", "Baeten, Elisabeth", Physics, University of Zurich, Winterthurerstrasse 190, CH-8057 Zurich, Switzerland), AT(Department of Physics, University of Zurich, Winterthurerstrasse 190, CH-8057 Zurich, Switzerland), AU(Institute of Cosmology and Gravitation, University of Portsmouth, Dennis Sciama Building, Portsmouth P01 3FX, UK)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "455", "publication_year": "2016/01/1", "start_page": "1191", "end_page": "1210", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: statistical", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016MNRAS.455.1191M", "abstract": "We report the discovery of 29 promising (and 59 total) new lens candidates from the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS) based on about 11 million classifications performed by citizen scientists as part of the first SPACE WARPS lens search. The goal of the blind lens search was to identify lens candidates missed by robots (the RINGFINDER on galaxy scales and ARCFINDER on group/cluster scales) which had been previously used to mine the CFHTLS for lenses. We compare some properties of the samples detected by these algorithms to the SPACE WARPS sample and find them to be broadly similar. The image separation distribution calculated from the SPACE WARPS sample shows that previous constraints on the average density profile of lens galaxies are robust. SPACE WARPS recovers about 65 per cent of known lenses, while the new candidates show a richer variety compared to those found by the two robots. This detection rate could be increased to 80 per cent by only using classifications performed by expert volunteers (albeit at the cost of a lower purity), indicating that the training and performance calibration of the citizen scientists is very important for the success of SPACE WARPS. In this work we present the SIMCT pipeline, used for generating in situ a sample of realistic simulated lensed images. This training sample, along with the false positives identified during the search, has a legacy value for testing future lens-finding algorithms. We make the pipeline and the training set publicly available.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stv1965", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1504.05587", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "2"}, "Inspection status": "Incomplete"}
